Shane McMahon announced his resignation from WWE in 2009, effective January 1, 2010.

Tom Baker is an English actor best known for portraying the fourth Doctor in Doctor Who from 1974 to 1981, the longest tenure of any actor in the role. He has also narrated the comedy series Little Britain, as well as commercials, video games, audiobooks, and television series.
Angelsberg is a small town located in the commune of Fischbach in central Luxembourg.

The Hanford Site includes a cleanup project, a commercial nuclear power plant called the Columbia Generating Station, and centers for scientific research and development like the Pacific Northwest National Laboratory and the LIGO Hanford Observatory.

The White House Press Secretary is a senior official appointed by the President to serve as the spokesperson for the executive branch, focusing on the President, senior executives, and policies. The role does not require Senate approval and is a prominent non-Cabinet position due to its frequent media briefings.

Kentucky, known as the "Bluegrass State" for its fertile soil and bluegrass pastures, features the central Bluegrass Region containing major cities Louisville and Lexington. The state is recognized for horse racing, bourbon distilleries, coal, the historic My Old Kentucky Home site, automobile manufacturing, tobacco, bluegrass music, college basketball, and Kentucky Fried Chicken.
Broken Bridges is a 2006 film starring Toby Keith, Lindsey Haun, Burt Reynolds, and Kelly Preston. Kelly Preston also appeared in the films The Cat in the Hat and Old Dogs.
Kesha Rose Sebert, born March 1, 1987, is an American singer, songwriter, and rapper, formerly stylized as Ke $ ha.
On May 5, 2017, two versions of "Despacito" were released: an electronic version produced by American trio Major Lazer and Colombian DJ MOSKA, and an urban version produced by Sky.

Starrcade was an annual professional wrestling event held from 1983 to 2000 by the NWA and later WCW. It began as a closed-circuit television broadcast and became the first NWA event broadcast on pay-per-view in 1987. The event faced competition from WWF’s Survivor Series that year, which sought exclusivity on Thanksgiving night. Earlier Starrcades (1983–1986) were later added to the WWE Network’s pay-per-view section in 2014 and rated TV-MA for violent content. The 1997 Starrcade marked the fifteenth annual pay-per-view event in the series.
Veeru Devgan is an Indian Bollywood stunt and action choreographer and film director.
Star Trek: Discovery is the first Star Trek series developed specifically for its streaming service and the first new Star Trek series since Star Trek: Enterprise ended in 2005.

Terry Crews played as a defensive end and linebacker in the NFL for the Los Angeles Rams, San Diego Chargers, and Washington Redskins, and also played in the World League of American Football with Rhein Fire.

The passage provides information on three subjects titled "Excuse My French": it is the debut studio album by American rapper French Montana; a 2014 Egyptian comedy film directed by Amr Salama, based on his middle school experiences; and also mentions Benjamin Paul Ballance-Drew (Plan B), a British hip hop artist and filmmaker.
A floppy disk is a type of disk storage consisting of a thin, flexible magnetic disk enclosed in a rectangular plastic casing lined with fabric to remove dust.

Guatemala experienced chronic instability and civil strife from the mid-19th century onward. Between 1960 and 1996, it endured a bloody civil war between the US-backed government and leftist rebels, during which the military committed genocidal massacres against the Maya population.
Forceps are handheld, hinged instruments used for grasping and holding objects. Outside of medicine, they are commonly known as tweezers, tongs, pliers, clips, or clamps.
The Closer began its seventh and final season on Monday, July 11, 2011, following its sixth season as the highest-rated cable drama.

Dr. Jack Shephard is the protagonist of the ABC drama series Lost, portrayed by Matthew Fox. Lost aired from September 22, 2004, to May 23, 2010, spanning six seasons and 121 episodes, with its first season averaging 16 million viewers per episode.

Matthew McConaughey, born November 4, 1969, is an American actor known for favoring dramatic roles since 2011. Notable films from this period include The Lincoln Lawyer (2011), Bernie (2011), Killer Joe (2011), The Paperboy (2012), Mud (2012), Magic Mike (2012), The Wolf of Wall Street (2013), Dallas Buyers Club (2013), Interstellar (2014), The Sea of Trees (2016), and Free State of Jones (2016). The film Mud (2012) also stars Tye Sheridan, Jacob Lofland, Sam Shepard, and Reese Witherspoon alongside McConaughey.

Robert Palmer was a writer known for his books such as Deep Blues, his music journalism for the New York Times and Rolling Stone, his work producing blues recordings and the Deep Blues film soundtrack, and his clarinet playing in the 1960s band the Insect Trust.

James Lincoln de la Mothe Borglum (1912–1986) was an American sculptor, photographer, author, and engineer. He is best known for completing the Mount Rushmore National Memorial after the death of his father, Gutzon Borglum, who originally designed and led the project from 1927 until his death in 1941. Lincoln Borglum took over leadership of the construction following his father's passing.

Underdog is a film directed by Frederik Du Chau and written by Joe Piscatella, Adam Rifkin, and Craig A. Williams. It stars Jim Belushi, Peter Dinklage, John Slattery, and Patrick Warburton, with voice roles by Jason Lee, Amy Adams, and Brad Garrett.

The TV series "The 100" follows a group of teens—Clarke Griffin, Bellamy Blake, Octavia Blake, Jasper Jordan, Monty Green, Raven Reyes, Finn Collins, John Murphy, and Wells Jaha—who are among the first from a space habitat called "The Ark" to return to Earth after a nuclear apocalypse. The series also features Dr. Abby Griffin (Clarke’s mother), Marcus Kane (an Ark council member), and Thelonious Jaha (the Ark’s Chancellor and Wells’ father).

The Concert for Bangladesh, despite facing financial issues due to its pioneering nature, is recognized as a successful and influential humanitarian aid project that raised awareness, generated significant funds, and inspired future initiatives like Live Aid.
Mani Ratnam is recognized as an influential Indian filmmaker who revolutionized the Tamil film industry and transformed Indian cinema.

The Freeport Doctrine, presented by Stephen A. Douglas during the second Lincoln-Douglas debate on August 27, 1858, in Freeport, Illinois, was part of a series of seven debates between Abraham Lincoln and Douglas, who were competing for the U.S. Senate seat from Illinois. These debates, particularly those in Freeport, Quincy, and Alton, attracted large audiences due to the critical national issue of slavery.

Easy A is a 2010 American teen comedy film directed by Will Gluck, written by Bert V. Royal, and starring Emma Stone alongside a supporting cast including Stanley Tucci, Patricia Clarkson, and others.

Anne Rice, born Howard Allen Frances O'Brien on October 4, 1941, is an American author known for gothic fiction, Christian literature, and erotica. She began her professional writing career with the 1976 publication of Interview with the Vampire in California and continued writing its sequels in the 1980s. Initially receiving mixed reviews, her popularity grew among critics and readers during the 1980s. She was married to poet and painter Stan Rice for 41 years until his death from brain cancer in 2002.

Camden is a city in Camden County, New Jersey, with a 2010 population of 77,344, making it the 12th most populous municipality in the state. Its early 20th-century population was primarily composed of European immigrants.
Bret Easton Ellis wrote the screenplay for the 2013 American erotic thriller-drama film The Canyons, directed by Paul Schrader, which received critical derision.

The Lincoln-Douglas Debates of 1858 were seven debates between Abraham Lincoln, the Republican Senate candidate from Illinois, and incumbent Senator Stephen Douglas, the Democratic candidate, held in seven Illinois towns.

The passage states that Homer is the ancient Greek author attributed with writing the Iliad and the Odyssey, central works of Greek literature. It also mentions that The Thicket is a mystery/suspense novel by American author Joe R. Lansdale.
Christopher Scott Kyle (April 8, 1974 – February 2, 2013) was a U.S. Navy SEAL sniper who was murdered by Eddie Ray Routh on February 2, 2013, at a shooting range near Chalk Mountain, Texas.

The passage details three interconnected rock bands and key members. Audioslave was a four-piece band featuring Chris Cornell from Soundgarden and Rage Against the Machine members Tom Morello, Tim Commerford, and Brad Wilk. Brad Wilk is primarily known as the drummer for Rage Against the Machine (1991–2000; 2007–2011) and Audioslave (2001–2007), starting his career in 1990 with Greta and co-founding Rage Against the Machine in 1991. As of 2016, Wilk plays in Prophets of Rage alongside Commerford, Morello, and others. Rage Against the Machine, formed in 1991, included Zack de la Rocha (vocals), Tim Commerford (bass/backing vocals), Tom Morello (guitar), and Brad Wilk (drums).

Janelle Monáe Robinson, born December 1, 1985, is an American singer, songwriter, actress, and model signed to Wondaland Arts Society and Atlantic Records. In 2010, she released her critically acclaimed debut full-length studio album, The ArchAndroid, a concept album sequel to her first EP, released by Bad Boy Records.
Winter's Tale is a novel written by Mark Helprin, published in 1983.

Lake Providence is the parish seat of East Carroll Parish in northeastern Louisiana. The passage also notes that at the University of Mississippi, about 55% of undergraduates and 60% overall students are from Mississippi, 23% are minorities, and international students represent 90 nations.
The series "Flaked" was renewed in July 2016 for a six-episode second season set to premiere on June 2, 2017.

Aaron Burr served in the New York State Assembly twice (1784–1785, 1798–1799), was New York State Attorney General (1789–1791), a U.S. senator from New York (1791–1797), and ultimately became vice president.

The Soyuz rocket was developed by the Korolyov Design Bureau in the 1960s for the Soviet space program to launch Soyuz spacecraft. Initially, it conducted 8 unmanned test flights followed by 19 manned launches. Designed as a successor to the Voskhod spacecraft and originally part of Soviet manned lunar efforts, the Soyuz series remains in service today.
Steve Ditko studied under Batman artist Jerry Robinson at the Cartoonist and Illustrators School in New York City.

Rage Against the Machine disbanded in 2000 after lead vocalist Zack de la Rocha quit due to tensions. De la Rocha pursued a solo career, while the remaining members formed Audioslave with Chris Cornell, releasing three albums before splitting in 2007. That same year, Rage Against the Machine reunited and performed at Coachella. Their fourth studio album, Renegades, was released in December 2000.

The S&P BSE SENSEX, also known as the BSE 30 or SENSEX, is a free-float market-weighted stock index of 30 financially sound companies listed on the Bombay Stock Exchange. Tata Motors is one such company, listed on the BSE (part of the SENSEX), the National Stock Exchange of India, and the New York Stock Exchange.

Vietnam, officially the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, is the easternmost country on the Indochina Peninsula in Southeast Asia with an estimated population of 92.7 million, making it the 14th-most-populous country globally and ninth in Asia. It is bordered by China, Laos, Cambodia, Thailand, the Philippines, Malaysia, and Indonesia. Since 2000, Vietnam has experienced one of the highest economic growth rates worldwide and led the Global Growth Generators Index among 11 major economies in 2011. It is one of the four remaining one-party socialist states officially practicing communism.
Dreamer is a 2005 American sports drama film, marking John Gatins' directorial debut.

Bhagat Singh was a charismatic Indian socialist revolutionary known for two dramatic acts of violence against the British and was executed at age 23, becoming a folk hero of the Indian independence movement after his death.
Aparshakti Khurana made his Bollywood debut with the 2016 Hindi-language biographical sports drama film "Dangal," directed by Nitesh Tiwari and starring Aamir Khan.

James VI and I (1566–1625) was King of Scotland from 1567 and King of England and Ireland from 1603, ruling both kingdoms in a personal union though they remained separate sovereign states with distinct parliaments, laws, and judiciaries. He advocated for a unified parliament for England and Scotland and faced significant challenges with the English Parliament during his reign.

Danielle Cormack, born on 26 December 1970, is a New Zealand stage and screen actress known for her roles in the soap opera Shortland Street, Xena: Warrior Princess (as Ephiny), The Cult, and Legend of the Seeker. She has appeared in the film Separation City (2009) and the Australian series Rake, and portrayed Kate Leigh in Underbelly: Razor. Her most notable recent role was Bea Smith in the Foxtel prison drama Wentworth, starring for four years until 2016.
Rob Sheridan (born October 11, 1979) is an American graphic designer, director, and photographer, notable for his extensive work with the band Nine Inch Nails.

David Spade starred in films including Tommy Boy, Black Sheep, Joe Dirt, Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser, Grown Ups, and Grown Ups 2. Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser is a 2015 American comedy directed by Fred Wolf and co-written by David Spade and Fred Wolf.
Angela Evelyn Bassett, born on August 16, 1958, is an American actress.

Artpop received mixed critical reviews but was commercially successful, debuting at number one on the US Billboard 200 with 258,000 first-week sales. It was Lady Gaga's second consecutive US number-one album, selling 757,000 copies domestically and 2.3 million worldwide in 2013, making it the ninth best-selling album of that year.
John Frusciante was the guitarist for the Chili Peppers, with his fifth and final album with the band being 2006's Stadium Arcadium. He confirmed his departure from the band in 2009.
Margaret Thatcher, as Prime Minister, implemented policies known as Thatcherism. She remains a controversial yet highly influential figure in British history, with ongoing debates about her policies.

Michael Andrew "Duff" McKagan (born February 5, 1964) is an American musician, singer, songwriter, and author who has also written weekly columns on various topics for SeattleWeekly.com, Playboy.com, and ESPN.com.
Tom Baker is an English actor who has performed acting roles and also narrated commercials, video games, audiobooks, and television series.

Valencia is the capital of the autonomous community of Valencia in Spain and the country's third largest city after Madrid and Barcelona, with approximately 800,000 residents in the city center. Its metropolitan area has a population between 1.7 and 2.5 million. The Valencian Community is an autonomous region in Spain, with Valencia as its largest city and metropolitan area.
Buffy Summers is a character portrayed by Kristy Swanson in the film and by Sarah Michelle Gellar in the television series.
The series "Make It or Break It" ended with its third and final season, concluding with the series finale aired on May 14, 2012.

Speech recognition (SR) is an interdisciplinary field within computational linguistics that develops technologies enabling computers to convert spoken language into text. It draws from linguistics, computer science, and electrical engineering. Applications include voice user interfaces for tasks like voice dialing, call routing, appliance control, search, data entry, document preparation, speech-to-text processing, and aircraft control. The field has seen significant advances through deep learning methods, reflected both in academic research and broad industry adoption by major companies such as Google, Microsoft, IBM, Baidu, Apple, Amazon, and others.

Richard Alf (1952–2012) was an American businessman and former comic book store owner who co-founded the San Diego Comic-Con International in 1970. Initially named the Golden State Comic Book Convention, it was founded by Alf along with Shel Dorf, Ken Krueger, and Mike Towry, and later renamed the San Diego Comic Book Convention. Alf also served as its chairman starting in 1970.
The passage states that Fist of Legend is a remake of the 1972 film Fist of Fury, which originally starred Bruce Lee as the lead character.

France's Dubuisson and South Africa's Van Zyl share the lead at 16 under par after carding 67s. Rory McIlroy, with a third consecutive 67, is at 15 under par alongside Thailand's Kiradech Aphibarnrat. McIlroy's round included an eagle on the 12th hole; he aims to secure his first title since May. Despite early setbacks during the round, McIlroy recovered strongly. He recently returned from an ankle injury sustained in July and is targeting a third Race to Dubai title, currently leading by a significant margin with three events remaining. English players Chris Wood and Richard Bland, previously tied for second, now sit fifth and seventh.

Sheikh Ali Salman of al-Wefaq emphasized that meaningful national dialogue in Bahrain requires the government's genuine willingness to provide concrete solutions and representation from a reform-minded royal family member, notably Crown Prince Salman al-Khalifa. The government is divided, with hardliners opposing concessions fearing they will encourage further opposition demands. Despite skepticism among youth toward traditional opposition, Salman advocates working with reformists within the Sunni royal family. He recalled a thwarted 2011 seven-point plan agreed with the crown prince to move toward a constitutional monarchy, halted by GCC troop intervention. Salman expressed hope that US Secretary of State John Kerry would adopt a stronger stance on Bahrain's human rights issues than his predecessor and criticized the UK for private rather than public pressure on the Bahraini government. Al-Wefaq will continue peaceful demonstrations despite bans and demands the release of 13 opposition leaders convicted on questionable grounds, arguing their inclusion is vital for successful dialogue.

Christopher Hogwood, a pioneer of the early-music movement, died at his Cambridge home after months of illness. He founded and directed the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) for about 30 years, leading it globally and producing over 200 recordings, including the first complete Mozart symphony cycle on period instruments. Renowned for his influential recordings like the 1980 Handel's Messiah, Hogwood studied keyboard at Cambridge and held roles with prestigious ensembles and festivals. He also taught at Harvard, Cambridge, and Cornell. Colleagues and artists praised his generosity, intellect, and dedication to historically informed music, highlighting his lasting legacy in early music performance. The funeral was private, with a memorial planned later.

The passage reports that in the year ending March 2016, Scotland recorded 57 homicide victims, the lowest annual total since 1976 and half the number from nine years prior, with only one unresolved case. Sharp instruments, mostly knives, accounted for 51% of killings. Police noted that 31% of accused individuals were under the influence of alcohol or drugs. Justice Secretary Michael Matheson highlighted ongoing efforts in education, enforcement, and community support to sustain the decline in violent crime. Scottish Labour’s Claire Baker cautioned about the reliability of such statistics, noting prior revisions increased past homicide figures and highlighted rising rates of sexual and violent crimes despite the homicide decline.

Bournemouth lost 2-1 to Sunderland, marking Sunderland's first Premier League win this season. Dan Gosling scored Bournemouth's first goal in three games. Despite creating many chances, Bournemouth failed to score after Gosling's goal, including when Sunderland played with 10 men following Steven Pienaar's red card. Manager Howe emphasized it wasn’t due to lack of confidence and stressed the importance of moving on from the result.

The passage discusses Australian Prime Minister Mr Abbott's stance on stopping migrant deaths at sea by preventing boat arrivals to Australia, which detains migrants and sends them to offshore processing camps. The New York Times criticized this policy as "brutal," "inhumane," and legally questionable, warning against Europe adopting similar measures. Abbott acknowledged the tragedy of a Syrian child's death but insisted stopping boats was necessary to prevent drownings. Additionally, Abbott sparked controversy by comparing Islamic State (IS) to the Nazis, claiming IS was worse because it boasts of its evil, prompting criticism from Australian Jewish groups for making an inappropriate comparison. Abbott stood by his remarks, clarifying he was not ranking evil.

The US blamed Russia and the Syrian government for escalating attacks on civilians in Aleppo, warning it would halt talks unless Moscow stopped bombing the city. Following the collapse of a ceasefire, Aleppo has been heavily bombarded, including repeated strikes on a main trauma hospital in the rebel-held east, with hundreds of civilians killed and 250,000 trapped. The US suspended bilateral ceasefire talks with Russia, accusing Russia and Syrian forces of targeting hospitals and blocking humanitarian aid, citing the September 19 attack on an aid convoy. Russia denied responsibility for the convoy strike, blaming ground fire, and criticized the US for failing to improve humanitarian conditions and for not separating jihadists from moderate opposition. Consequently, planned US-Russia coordination meetings in Geneva were canceled, US personnel were withdrawn, but both sides agreed to continue counter-terrorism communications to prevent clashes.

The think tank Policy Exchange proposed selling high-value social homes when vacant to raise £4.5 billion annually, potentially funding 80,000 to 170,000 new social homes and sparking the largest social housebuilding program since the 1970s. Prime Minister’s officials support councils choosing this approach to use housing stock more efficiently and reduce the 1.8 million social housing waiting list. Policy Exchange argues this would reduce waiting by about 500,000 people and is supported by public opinion, claiming social housing would remain in expensive areas but in smaller numbers. Critics, including Labour and housing associations, warn it could displace low-income families from affluent neighborhoods, increasing segregation and breaking up communities. Labour advocates funding affordable homes through taxes and boosting construction, while Housing Minister Grant Shapps highlights government investment of £19.5 billion to build up to 170,000 homes and introduce fixed-term tenancies to prioritize those in greatest need.

Gareth Colfer-Williams, 25, died last week in Swansea, a city experiencing a measles outbreak with 942 cases. Although measles was confirmed via laboratory tests, it remains unclear if it was the primary cause of his death; further tests and an inquest are planned. Since the outbreak began in November, 83 people have been hospitalized for measles. Gareth had recently been treated for asthma and developed a rash shortly after hospital discharge. He saw a GP on April 17 with a widespread rash but was found dead the next morning. His family is uncertain how he contracted measles, as no close relatives, including his vaccinated three-year-old daughter, have the disease.

Vincent Hudson, 54, from Whitehaven, has been charged by Cumbria Police with a historical offence involving a boy under 16, dating back to 2001. He is scheduled to appear before North Cumbria Magistrates' Court.

Neil Aspin's Gateshead, unbeaten in nine National League matches, hosted Adam Lockwood's Guiseley, unbeaten in five. Guiseley took an early lead at 15 minutes through Jake Lawlor after a throw-in. Gateshead's goalkeeper and defender made key saves before halftime. In the second half, Gateshead equalized at 62 minutes with Wes York scoring after a slip by Guiseley's substitute Derek Asamoah. The match ended in a 1-1 draw, with several substitutions and yellow cards given during the game.

Bristol Sport Ltd plans to increase the football club's stadium capacity by replacing two stands, opting for this redevelopment instead of building a new stadium at Ashton Vale, which is delayed due to a town green application. Majority shareholder Steve Lansdown confirmed the council-approved work will begin after a judicial review period ending in March, with redevelopment starting in May if there are no challenges.

Cuadrilla suspended fracking operations in Lancashire as a precaution after a 1.5 magnitude earthquake near the Preese Hall drilling site, the second tremor in two months. The British Geological Survey (BGS) found the latest quake shared a similar location and mechanism with a previous 2.3 magnitude tremor on April 1. Fracking, involving injecting pressurized water or explosives to extract shale gas, can induce earthquakes due to rock fracturing. Cuadrilla is reviewing BGS data and consulting authorities before deciding to resume. While fracking has faced environmental concerns in the US, UK officials suggest risks can be managed through regulation. The BGS continues to monitor seismic activity near the site, with recent tremors occurring about 2 km deep and close to the drilling location.

Angus Carpenter, a Liverpool piper with over 30 years of experience, was found guilty of one count of fraud related to playing with a Hillsborough Justice Campaign banner on his bagpipes in April 2015, but cleared of two other counts. He was accused of giving the impression he was collecting money for the charity, which he denied, stating he was simply busking and using the banner as a tribute, not to deceive. The charity’s chairman confirmed Carpenter had permission to display the banner but not to collect funds. Carpenter is known as a busker associated with the campaign and will be sentenced in January.

Ipswich Town defeated Queens Park Rangers (QPR) 3-0 in a Championship match. Grant Ward opened the scoring for Ipswich, followed by Luke Varney capitalizing on a QPR keeper Alex Smithies' clearance error to score the second. Tom Lawrence sealed the victory with a composed finish. Ipswich, previously struggling to score, dominated chances and improved to 14th place, while QPR fell to 15th. Ipswich manager Mick McCarthy praised Varney's performance and acknowledged Smithies' mistake but valued the win. QPR boss Ian Holloway criticized his team's mental toughness and defensive errors, particularly around the second goal. Despite some QPR attempts, Ipswich controlled most of the game and finished strong.

Wells, 23, performed well in last season's T20 Blast, scoring 373 runs at an average of 28.69 with a strike rate of 138.66. He expressed enthusiasm about the club’s progress, praising the coaches for creating an elite performance environment that motivates the players.

The Reds, currently fifth in National Two South, secured a 29-12 victory over third-placed Chinnor, marking their second consecutive win. Key players Tommy Phillips, Ben Priddey, and Craig Williams led strong defensive efforts, with the front row making over 70 tackles. Upcoming matches include seven teams ranked below them and league leaders Old Elthamians. Despite the win, coach Churcher emphasized the need for improvement and building on their recent performance.

A 28-year-old man named Nazrul (Nazu), allegedly a Bangladeshi citizen, was arrested in Kolkata for raping a 74-year-old nun during an attack on a convent in Ranaghat on March 14. The incident sparked nationwide protests in India. Nazrul, the sixth arrest in the case, was identified from CCTV footage and tracked after fleeing to Bangladesh. Police have named eight suspects, with two still at large. Earlier arrests include Milon Sarkar, described as the gang leader, though his exact role is unclear. During the attack, money was stolen and the convent was ransacked before the nun was assaulted.

The passage describes an interactive video featuring Robert Opie, founder of the Museum of Brands, Packaging and Advertising, discussing key reasons behind changes in UK consumer purchasing, such as the introduction of domestic freezers, washing powder, and cheaper imports. It also explores shifts in ownership and ranking of major UK brands. A non-interactive version and additional related resources are provided for users with older browsers.

Two women, aged 71 and from Sandyhills and Stranraer respectively, were scammed by callers pretending to be BT representatives offering technical support. The scammers gained remote access to their computers and stole money. The incidents occurred on 15 September and a week later. PC Siobhan Pellett warned the public to be cautious of cold calls seeking remote computer access and emphasized never sharing banking details over the phone, as legitimate businesses do not request such information.

Duffy, 37, has signed a one-year contract to coach third-placed Championship side Featherstone after leaving Swinton Lions. As Scotland's assistant coach, he will lead Featherstone in their final league game against Toulouse and the upcoming Super 8 Qualifiers. Chairman Mark Campbell praised Duffy's coaching abilities and his achievements at Swinton under difficult circumstances. Duffy, who had a 16-year playing career with Leigh, Widnes, and Salford, was succeeded at Swinton by his former assistant Stuart Littler.

A Porthcawl RNLI crew, a medic, and the coastguard helicopter responded to Sker Beach at 12:50 GMT on Sunday to assist a rider with head injuries who was unconscious on wet sand. The rider was treated on site before being airlifted to Cardiff's University Hospital of Wales.

The UN's World Radiocommunication Conference in Geneva decided to allocate part of the radio spectrum for a global satellite-based flight tracking system, improving on current ground-based radar coverage which misses about 70% of airspace. This system will enable satellites to receive automatic dependent surveillance-broadcast (ADS-B) transmissions from aircraft, allowing real-time tracking worldwide. The move follows the disappearance of Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 in 2014, which revealed weaknesses in flight tracking. The ITU responded swiftly to global calls for better tracking, with the UN's aviation agency ICAO setting a November 2016 deadline for new guidelines requiring aircraft to send position updates at least every 15 minutes, or more frequently during emergencies.

Julian Hernandez, who disappeared at age five and is now 18, was found living with his father in Cleveland. Bobby Hernandez, 53, was arrested in Ohio and is held on charges including tampering with records to obtain a driver's license in 2012. The FBI identified Julian after a tip related to college application issues and confirmed his identity with Alabama police and the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children. Julian's mother has been notified. Authorities suspected Bobby Hernandez around the time of the disappearance, as he fled after claiming to take his son to preschool in 2002. Bobby is held at Cuyahoga County Jail with $250,000 bail.

Firefighters spent several days addressing a fire on 2 March at a site on Duncan Street, which disrupted train services and travel. Following the blaze, the Environment Agency (EA) suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited from accepting waste by revoking its environmental permit, effective 7 August unless appealed. The fire service described the firm, operated by Asset and Land Group, as "broadly compliant" with fire safety laws. Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service visited the site nine times in the past year and expressed concerns about potential impacts on residents, transport, and the environment, prompting joint inspections with the EA. The cause of the fire remains unknown.

The pro-Kremlin party A Just Russia introduced two bills linked to the Ukraine crisis, especially focusing on Crimea where pro-Russian sentiments are strong. One bill would allow Russian MPs to accept territories whose populations clearly wish to join Russia without needing a treaty from the neighboring state, a change from current law designed for peaceful times. The second bill aims to fast-track and simplify Russian passport issuance for Ukrainians, waiving fees, residence requirements, and the need to renounce Ukrainian citizenship. This bill targets Russian-speaking Ukrainians “defenceless” against perceived threats and reduces citizenship wait times from one year to two months. The proposals reflect Russia’s previous actions in Georgian territories and have been publicly supported by Russian MPs and notable figures visiting Crimea.

The passage outlines McLaren's fall from past Formula 1 greatness to current struggles, highlighting their historical successes—182 race wins, 12 drivers' championships, and eight constructors' titles—and notable drivers like Fernando Alonso. Their decline began in 2013 due to chassis design issues, compounded by problems with the Honda power unit after rekindling that partnership, a contrast to their dominant 1988-1992 era with Honda engines and legends Ayrton Senna and Alain Prost. Scandals in 2007 and 2009, including illegal technical data possession and misleading officials, further marred their reputation. Despite recoveries with drivers like Mika Hakkinen and Lewis Hamilton, recent years have seen few victories. Under Ron Dennis’s leadership, who regained control after 2013, McLaren aims to rebuild and break Mercedes' dominance, banking on improved Honda engines and Alonso’s return as a catalyst for future championships. Currently, belief in recovery remains their strongest asset amid ongoing performance challenges.

Tommy Baker, 44, from Everton, Liverpool, was shot in the head and chest outside Stanley Meat Market on 27 January after leaving Phoenix Gym and later died in hospital. Three Liverpool men aged 29, 29, and 32 remain in police custody. Police believe the shooters waited outside the gym for about an hour. Authorities are searching for a silver VW Polo that fled the scene and are seeking witnesses captured on CCTV near the market who have not yet come forward.

The passage discusses various contemporary, online ways to enjoy and share the spiritual aspects of Christmas while incorporating modern technology and media. It highlights Everyday Church Online, a UK-based virtual church service streaming sermons and facilitating global congregation interaction via chat. The church's Christmas theme draws parallels between Star Wars and hope in the holiday message. The fantasy mobile game Guardians of Ancora, developed by Scripture Union, engages children with Bible stories through gameplay, including Christmas-themed quests about Jesus' birth. Creative digital nativity presentations include Viral.de’s viral video told through social media updates and the Churches Advertising Network’s evolving-era ad, although the latter faced rejection from cinemas for being “too religious.” Next Manga produces Bible stories in Manga format, including a nativity edition, distributing millions worldwide and translating into numerous languages to reach diverse audiences, including refugees. Finally, social media platforms like Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram are used by Christian groups to share spiritual reflections during Christmas, emphasizing brief, thoughtful messages rather than direct Gospel sharing, with a note that Jesus would have been an effective communicator in today’s digital age.

The eight-day hearing in Ebbw Vale is reviewing a proposal to develop 250 hectares of common land, with supporters offering around 320 hectares of replacement land. Experts have presented conflicting views on environmental impacts: Natural Resources Wales found it hard to confirm the replacement land's equal value but did not oppose the project, while developers claimed a biodiversity net gain through habitat enhancements, which the Gwent Wildlife Trust disputed. The Planning Inspectorate for Wales will recommend a decision after the inquiry, with Welsh government ministers having the final approval.

The passage details a controversial report by Novaya Gazeta on 1 April revealing over 100 detentions and at least three killings of suspected homosexual men in Chechnya, with victims reportedly tortured. The Russian LGBT Network confirmed these allegations and is aiding victims to escape persecution, accusing Russian authorities of ignoring abuses and threatening to file an international case if no action is taken. Chechen Muslim clerics condemned the report as an insult to their faith and dignity, with their resolution implying retribution against instigators, which Novaya Gazeta interpreted as a threat to journalists. Chechen leader Ramzan Kadyrov denied the claims, asserting there were no gay people in Chechnya. Novaya Gazeta’s editor pledged to continue investigating human rights abuses despite previous murders of their journalists linked to Chechnya.

The passage describes how Investing Solutions, a letting agency, has profited over the past two years by housing single homeless men referred by the charity Fresh Start Housing, both based in south London and linked to founder Samir Patel. Fresh Start finds clients from London homeless charities, and Investing Solutions charges housing benefit for multiple unrelated tenants per property, earning significantly more than the rent paid to private landlords. While neither organization acts illegally, homeless advocates criticize the arrangement as exploitative. Tenants, like Nigel McCann, report poor living conditions in the properties. Nearly half of the housing benefit paid to Investing Solutions comes from Wandsworth Council, which states it monitors private rentals for safety. Fresh Start claims to have housed hundreds of homeless individuals but does not disclose details of those housed via Investing Solutions. Authorities emphasize local responsibility for safeguarding taxpayers’ money in private housing benefits.

In a closely contested warm-up game, Great Britain’s basketball team, coached by Joe Prunty, was overtaken in the final quarter by the Netherlands. London 2012 Olympian Andrew Lawrence led GB with 14 points, while NBA player Ben Gordon contributed 13, including three consecutive three-pointers in the third quarter to regain the lead. Despite GB's early advantage, the Dutch, led by Worthy De Jong’s 18 points, surged ahead in the fourth quarter to secure the win. Prunty emphasized the need for consistent effort in the upcoming Eurobasket qualifiers, beginning with a game in Hungary. He expressed satisfaction with Gordon’s performance as GB finalizes its roster for the qualifying campaign.

The passage details events leading up to Conor McGregor's boxing debut against Floyd Mayweather. McGregor submitted a waiver to the Nevada Athletic Commission (NAC) to allow the use of 8oz gloves instead of the mandated 10oz for a 154lb fight, a matter to be debated on 16 August. Mayweather had announced plans to wear 8oz gloves but had not submitted the waiver earlier. NAC director Bob Bennett explained that while 10oz gloves are standard above 135lbs, waivers can allow 8oz gloves if justified, with fighter safety paramount. Bennett, after reviewing McGregor's skills—including sparring insights and comparisons to fighters like Nate Diaz—recommended approving the fight, citing McGregor's toughness and youth versus Mayweather. McGregor's transition to boxing has drawn criticism from boxing figures. Bennett also advised hiring a boxing referee, resulting in Hall of Famer Joe Cortez joining the camp. Notably, sparring sessions revealed tensions, leading to Malignaggi's departure from McGregor's camp. This fight is poised to be one of the richest in history.

The passage chronicles the decline of Fleet Street as the historic hub of British journalism. Once the epicenter of national newspapers since the Daily Courant's launch in 1702, Fleet Street was famed for its concentration of media offices, journalist-filled pubs, and a vibrant print culture marked by typewriters and hot metal printing. Reporters Gavin Sherriff and Darryl Smith of the Sunday Post, both long-time Fleet Street journalists, recount personal memories and the street’s significant legacy. The move of major newspapers to modern, computerized printing facilities outside Fleet Street in the late 1980s, led notably by Rupert Murdoch’s relocation to Wapping, precipitated Fleet Street’s decline. The old press buildings have since been repurposed, symbolizing the end of an era. Former editor Robin Esser emphasizes Fleet Street’s past importance before television and social media dominated, while Liz Hodgkinson highlights the male-dominated, alcohol-heavy culture and the role of women journalists. With the closure of the Sunday Post’s London office and last Fleet Street journalists departing, the historic newspaper district’s final chapter has ended, preserving its place in media history.

J.K. Rowling expressed that positive comments remind her of the many decent people in the world, despite facing abusive tweets. She had previously stated her personal boundaries were crossed by some online abuse and emphasized standing up to bullies. Rowling faced major criticism after donating £1 million to the No campaign in the Scottish independence referendum and a similar amount to the Labour party in 2008. She revealed being called "a traitor" for her political views, blocking abusive users she believed were SNP supporters, while also engaging positively with other SNP supporters. Rowling humorously responded to a suggestion of burning her books. The SNP won 56 of 59 Scottish seats in a recent election, becoming the UK's third largest party.

The University of Edinburgh's study found that children from deprived backgrounds in Scotland are twice as likely to face police action and are about five times more likely to be placed on statutory supervision compared to better-off peers committing the same crimes. Poverty increases the likelihood of young people offending and experiencing violence, with boys being three times more likely than girls to engage in violence, and poorer girls twice as likely as affluent girls to be involved in violent crime. Prior contact with police strongly predicts youth disengagement from education and employment by age 18. Despite overall crime rates falling to a 41-year low, crime remains concentrated in the most deprived communities, which also face chronic health problems and high unemployment. Researchers highlight that poverty and contact with the justice system reinforce conditions for violence, while the Scottish government emphasizes ongoing efforts to reduce crime and tackle inequalities through significant investments.

Mr. Haugh, aged 25, was fatally stabbed in a laneway on the Marian estate in Kilkee early Sunday morning. Robbie Walsh from Kilrush was charged with assault causing serious harm and remanded in custody, with a court appearance scheduled for next week. Two other men arrested were released without charge, with files being prepared for the Director of Public Prosecutions. According to Detective Sergeant Padraig Frawley, Walsh and two others entered the estate around 1:00 a.m., sought Mr. Haugh, and engaged in a fight involving weapons, during which Haugh was stabbed in the back. Knives and golf clubs were recovered at the scene. Mr. Haugh was taken to Limerick University Hospital and pronounced dead at 6:00 a.m. A blood-stained knife blade was found. Due to tensions in Kilkee following the killing, the judge remanded Walsh in custody until 14 August.

The passage describes a legal case involving Sinn Féin MLA Phil Flanagan, who tweeted a defamatory statement about Tom Elliott, a former UDR member and current MP. The tweet falsely accused Elliott of harassing and shooting people during his UDR service. Elliott, with a clear Ministry of Defence record, challenged the tweet in the High Court. Flanagan deleted the tweet within an hour and must post an apology admitting the tweet was untrue. The court has reserved judgment on compensation, while Flanagan’s insurance refused to cover costs, prompting a separate legal challenge. Elliott stated he felt vindicated but disappointed by the delay in resolution.

Hawick Knitwear, employing over 230 staff, has increased sweater production from 7,500 to 9,500 weekly to meet rising demand driven by strong sales of its own brand launched in January and growth in private label orders. Founded in 1874 and acquired by managing director Benny Hartop in November last year, the company supplies markets across Europe and internationally, including the USA, Canada, Mexico, and Japan. Hartop attributes the success to dedicated staff and expects continued growth despite challenges.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady with 20 years' experience, suffered serious head injuries last December outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston after being hit by Brian Wright's car. Wright, 55, admitted striking her but denies dangerous driving, claiming he was blinded by the setting sun and failed to stop at a red light. Mrs. Blackburn was escorting a child across the road when the collision occurred. She is now in residential care. Wright expressed remorse in court, and the trial is ongoing.

The passage discusses a Nato anti-submarine exercise named "Dynamic Mongoose," conducted in response to increased Russian submarine activity in Northern waters. The exercise involves hunting for the German U-boat U33, which simulates an enemy submarine attempting to evade detection and target Nato ships, including the USS Vicksburg. Rear Admiral Brad Williamson emphasizes the importance of such realistic training due to heightened Russian submarine presence near Sweden, Finland, and the UK.

The exercise highlights the difficulty in detecting stealthy submarines and the advanced capabilities of Russia's modern fleet of around 60 submarines, which includes highly skilled crews and technologically advanced, quiet vessels. Nato employs warships, anti-submarine helicopters, maritime patrol aircraft (provided by allies like France since the UK lacks its own), underwater drones, and sonar monitoring to track submarines.

A significant concern raised is the UK's defensive gap, notably the absence of its own long-range maritime patrol aircraft since retiring the Nimrod, forcing reliance on Nato allies for aerial surveillance. Experts warn this weakness makes the UK vulnerable to Russian submarine tracking near critical sites like the Faslane naval base. The passage stresses the necessity for Nato readiness in anti-submarine warfare and calls for Britain to address its capability gaps in upcoming defence reviews, as confronting real Russian submarines will be more challenging than exercises against U33.

The passage details the escalating ethnic violence and humanitarian crisis in South Sudan, particularly since July when conflict spread from Juba to the southern Equatoria states. Over 340,000 South Sudanese refugees have fled mostly to Uganda, surpassing Syria's refugee outflow this year. Refugees recount brutal ethnic-based killings, rapes, and targeting primarily by Dinka forces against Equatorians and Nuer. Uganda has responded generously, quickly allocating land and resources to refugees, with large settlements like Bidi Bidi growing into some of the world's biggest. However, Uganda is beginning to face challenges supplying necessities amid the nearly one million refugees. The UN and aid workers call for international attention and pressure on South Sudanese leaders to end the violence, which has devastated communities and traumatized countless children and families.

McKenzie, aged 38, will fight Jahmaine Smyle for the English super-middleweight title at York Hall on 12 November. A former footballer who turned professional boxer in 2013, McKenzie has an 8-0-1 record. He is the son of ex-champion Clinton McKenzie and trained by his uncle, three-time world champion Duke McKenzie.

The coalition is investing £330m in new NHS facilities across England, including £33m for a new Bridgwater Community Hospital. The new hospital will feature 30 inpatient beds, a midwifery-led maternity unit, a minor injury unit, X-ray facilities, and mobile scanner space. The current hospital, built in 1813, is outdated and cramped. NHS Somerset and Somerset Partnership NHS Foundation Trust will fund the remaining costs. The new build aims to improve patient recovery and well-being. In recent years, three of Somerset’s 13 community hospitals have been replaced, with additional developments at Musgrove Park Hospital underway. The new Bridgwater hospital is planned for Bowers Lane, pending planning permission, with completion targeted for autumn 2014.

A man was fatally shot outside a property on Daniel Hill Terrace, Upperthorpe, near Sheffield city centre, around 13:35 GMT. He was near or inside a black Mercedes when shot in the chest and later died at Northern General hospital. The victim was part of a family gathered nearby for a celebration. Armed police secured the scene. Recent weeks have seen several shootings in Sheffield, mostly in northern areas like Shiregreen, Southey Green, and High Green, but not previously near Upperthorpe.

The passage details the activities of three key hacker groups involved in the Ukraine conflict: the pro-Ukrainian Ukrainian Cyber Troops, the anti-Western Cyber Berkut, and the Russian-focused Anonymous International. The Ukrainian Cyber Troops, led by Yevhen Dokukin, employ DDoS attacks, hack Russian servers, and infiltrate CCTV and network printers to monitor and disrupt separatists. Cyber Berkut targets Ukrainian government websites and electoral systems, spreading anti-Western and pro-Russian messages, and claims to have accessed sensitive documents related to US military aid. Anonymous International leaks Kremlin and Russian domestic information, including materials linked to the Ukraine conflict, though its origins and methods remain unclear. These groups operate independently of governments but significantly impact information flow and warfare tactics in the ongoing conflict.

The passage describes emotional farewell speeches by outgoing MSPs Tricia Marwick, Duncan McNeil, Alex Salmond, and Annabel Goldie ahead of the May 5 election. Marwick was moved by McNeil’s final address, in which he urged Holyrood to improve accountability and scrutiny by learning from Westminster. Salmond, former First Minister, reiterated his belief that Scotland is diverse but not divided, praised the Scotland Bill’s power transfer to Holyrood, and highlighted the honor of serving as an MSP. He also made lighthearted jokes about contemporary events. Goldie humorously noted she would miss interactions with Finance Secretary John Swinney. All expressed gratitude for their parliamentary service as they stood down.

The Older People's Commissioner for Wales, Sarah Rochira, is conducting a review into the quality of life and care for older people in residential care across Wales. She is gathering experiences from pensioners, their families, care providers, social care staff, and public bodies to inform recommendations aimed at improving care. The review will assess factors like physical and psychological health, social relationships, and care home environments, highlighting both good care and the negative impacts of poor care. While the Care Forum Wales supports the review’s goals to promote best practices, it criticizes the absence of provider experts with direct care home experience on the advisory panel, expressing concern that this limits partnership and full sector engagement.

Harbro Group, based in Aberdeenshire, increased its pre-tax profit by £800,000 to £3.5 million for the year ending June 2016, despite a £1 million drop in turnover to just over £100 million. The company experienced growth in international sales across Europe and new markets. Harbro manufactures and supplies feeds for various livestock sectors and operates 19 Country Store shops in Scotland, serving rural communities. While acknowledging ongoing challenges in agriculture and uncertainties surrounding Brexit, the company remains confident in its robust position to face future business challenges.

A man in his 70s was found dead at a house in Little Gaddesden, near Berkhamsted, with an elderly man in his 80s hospitalized. Police are treating the death as murder and urgently seek 55-year-old Ian John McLoughlin (also known as Ian John Baker), describing his appearance and warning the public not to approach him. Investigations are ongoing, with increased police patrols in the area and appeals for information from the public.

David Lipton, deputy head of the IMF, highlighted risks to the global economy, noting a weakening baseline and a delicate situation. This follows China's exports dropping by 25% compared to the previous year. Consequently, the IMF plans to lower its global growth forecast, currently at 3.4%, in its April update. These developments negatively impact businesses and industries reliant on China's economic growth.

The council discussed issues with the new Cowes chain ferry, which since its late May launch has faced breakdowns, groundings, suspension over training problems, and vehicle damages. In response, council leader Dave Stewart announced free crossings until 2 July and an auditor review of the project. Local businesses report significant trade losses and seek compensation, which is under consideration. Transport councillor Ian Ward described the ferry as a prototype with expected teething problems, noting resolved electrical issues, authorized ramp extensions to prevent vehicle damage, and improved seamanship to address groundings.

A multi-vehicle crash occurred on the southbound carriageway near Hindhead tunnel at Bramshott around 07:30 GMT on Thursday, resulting in the death of a 32-year-old man at the scene. A 33-year-old man from Waterlooville was arrested on suspicion of causing death by careless driving. The road between Thursley and Liphook was closed until early evening for investigation.

Matching Models in London, an international temp agency for attractive and talented individuals, faced criticism for job adverts specifying physical appearance, such as a personal assistant with "a classic look, brown long hair with b-c cup" and a "sexy female driver" role. The Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) condemned the ads as unlawful and demeaning, warning the agency to clarify its hiring practices. Women's equality groups and employment lawyers highlighted these adverts likely breach equality laws by covertly discriminating based on age and gender. The agency defended its focus on clients' appearance preferences, citing specific client requests for physical traits tied to job roles or branding. Under the 2010 Equality Act, such discriminatory hiring criteria are illegal unless strictly essential for the job. The agency's founder acknowledged these demands stem from clients but faced calls to modernize practices and eliminate sexist criteria. The agency’s clients include major brands like MTV and Louis Vuitton, with some roles accommodating diverse looks such as tattooed models.

A shooting occurred at a hostel connected to Pragati Residential School in Bangalore, carried out by Mahesh, an office assistant at the school. On Tuesday evening, Mahesh shot 18-year-old Gautami in the head and another student, Sirisha, who was severely injured but is now stable. Mahesh was arrested following a manhunt and has been remanded until 12 April. Gun crime in Indian schools is rare, and the motive remains unclear. India enforces strict gun control laws despite frequent firearm-related feuds. A similar incident in 2007 involved a schoolboy being shot by fellow students near Delhi.

Between June 2016 and May 2017, Glaad identified 278 regular and recurring LGBT characters on TV, noting an increase in transgender characters from seven to 16. However, over 25 lesbian and bisexual female characters were killed off, including Poussey Washington and Bea Smith from popular shows. The study also recorded the highest percentage of black characters on broadcast TV, driven by series like Empire, Luke Cage, and How to Get Away with Murder. Glaad's report covered scripted broadcast, cable, and streaming series already airing or cast. While progress was acknowledged, Glaad's president emphasized that numbers alone don't tell the full story.

David Mackintosh, Conservative MP for Northampton South, announced he will not seek re-election amid controversy over a missing £10.25 million public loan linked to Northampton Town FC's stadium redevelopment, which occurred while he was council leader. The loan is under police investigation for alleged financial irregularities, and the football stadium remains unfinished. Despite initially intending to stand again, Mackintosh stepped down following local party opposition and denied any wrongdoing.

Roy Oliver, a 37-year-old former police officer, fatally shot 15-year-old Jordan Edwards in April in Balch Springs, Texas, after firing into a car leaving a party where underage drinking was reported. Oliver was fired for policy violations shortly after the incident. Initial police claims that the car reversed aggressively were disproven by footage showing it was driving away. Oliver faces a murder charge with a potential sentence of five to 99 years and four counts of aggravated assault related to the other teenagers in the car, including two of Edwards' brothers. No trial date has been set, and he is free on bail. If convicted, Oliver would be the first Dallas County officer convicted of murder since 1973. The district attorney emphasized thorough justice proceedings, while the victim was praised by his coach. The Edwards family’s lawyer expressed cautious optimism about the indictment given the rarity of police convictions in Texas.

The passage discusses Melania Trump's decision to delay moving to the White House with her son Barron until he finishes the school year, sparking mixed reactions. Historically, only two First Ladies did not reside in the White House while their husbands were presidents. Experts and precedents show it is common for presidential children to stay in their current schools mid-term. Previous presidential families, like the Clintons and Obamas, moved into the White House immediately, balancing public duties and family life. Melania has emphasized focusing on Barron and is expected to take a less public First Lady role, with cyber-bullying as a possible focus. Other family members, such as Ivanka Trump, might assist with responsibilities. Past First Ladies have varied in public visibility, balancing ceremonial roles with personal priorities, while maintaining family privacy.

A 72-year-old man died in Inverness on 27 October. The Police Investigations and Review Commissioner (Pirc), Kate Frame, has been tasked by the Crown Office and Procurator Fiscal Service (COPFS) to investigate the initial police response to the man's call. Police Scotland is fully cooperating and awaiting the investigation's outcome, which will be reported to COPFS in due course.

A yellow wind warning was issued, forecasting gusts up to 75 mph (120 km/h), especially west of the mountains, with unusual easterly winds potentially increasing the impact. Travel disruptions on roads and at sea are expected in Conwy, Anglesey, Gwynedd, Pembrokeshire, Carmarthenshire, Ceredigion, and Powys. Overnight gusts caused a tree to fall in Menai Bridge, Anglesey, closing Telford Road, which will likely remain closed most of Monday for cleanup.

The Giants started short-handed with player-coach Derrick Walser, but Jeff Dimmen equalized for the Panthers. In the second period, Mike Forney scored a powerplay breakaway goal to make it 2-1, followed by Andy Bohmbach's equalizer. Mike Radja and James Desmarais then scored to make it 4-2, before Nottingham's David Ling reduced the deficit. The teams will meet again Saturday night for the second game of their double-header. Nottingham leads the league with 28 points, followed by Sheffield Steelers with 27 and Belfast with 25.

The passage describes a chaotic Chinese Grand Prix where World Champion Lewis Hamilton started from the back after an early incident causing a broken front wing and requiring five pit stops. Despite a strong recovery, Hamilton finished behind several key rivals and now faces a 36-point deficit to teammate Nico Rosberg, who led the race calmly after his competitor Daniel Ricciardo suffered a puncture. Ferrari's Sebastian Vettel finished second despite colliding with teammate Kimi Raikkonen on the opening lap; Raikkonen recovered to fifth, outpacing Hamilton late in the race aided by Ferrari's tyre strategy. Multiple first-lap collisions triggered a safety car, affecting race dynamics. Vettel publicly criticized Daniil Kvyat over a risky overtaking move. Mercedes' Hamilton suffered significant car damage, impacting his pace and championship chances, while Rosberg's strong and steady drive extended his points lead, making it harder for Hamilton to defend his title.

Thomas Hitzlsperger publicly came out as homosexual in an interview with Die Zeit, aiming to address the taboo of homosexuality in German football. His announcement received widespread praise from former teammates, football figures, clubs like Bayern Munich, and German football administrators, who called it a courageous and important step against homophobia. It marked a historic moment, as he was the first prominent German footballer to do so, highlighting ongoing struggles with intolerance in the sport. The German government and openly gay politicians also expressed support, hoping this would encourage others to come out and break down stigmas. Leaders in football hope this will lead to greater acceptance and openness regarding sexuality in the sport.

Sidwell, 34, has made 32 appearances this season, helping Brighton gain promotion to the Premier League for the first time in 34 years. With his contract expiring at the season's end, he hopes to sign a new deal, confident Brighton can stay in the top flight. Having previously played for several Premier League clubs, Sidwell believes his strong performance this season has earned him the chance to continue playing at the highest level. Brighton confirmed promotion after defeating Wigan and currently lead the Championship by four points with two games remaining.

The match between Blackpool and Colchester United ended in a 1-1 draw. Blackpool took the lead after 12 minutes with Jamille Matt scoring following a precise pass from Nathan Delfouneso. Colchester equalized from a corner after Blackpool’s goalkeeper, Sam Slocombe, saved a shot but Kurtis Guthrie scored from the resulting scramble. Slocombe made key saves, including denying a late chance by George Elokobi and Guthrie hitting the bar. Blackpool missed a chance to win 15 minutes before the end when Tom Aldred headed wide from close range. The game ended with Colchester reduced to 10 men after substitute Sean Murray was sent off for a bad tackle in injury time. Numerous substitutions, fouls, and blocked attempts occurred throughout the match.

The 29-year-old Reid, who played 37 times for the Sky Blues last season during their League One relegation and has previously played for Charlton, Bradford, and Preston, may debut for Colchester U's in Wednesday's EFL Cup first-round match against Aston Villa. Colchester began their season with a 3-1 loss to Accrington.

The murder of PC Keith Palmer outside the Houses of Parliament in March highlighted the need for a permanent police memorial. The UK Police Memorial Trust is raising £1.5 million for a memorial at the National Memorial Arboretum in Alrewas, Staffordshire, which will honor over 1,400 officers and staff who have died on duty over the past 250 years. The memorial will feature a brass screen with leaf shapes, each given to the families of fallen officers as a personal tribute. The government, through Home Secretary Amber Rudd, has pledged £1 million towards the £4 million total cost. The memorial aims to recognize the courage and sacrifice of police service members and is expected to be completed by 2019.

Manchester United remain 15 points clear at the top of the Premier League with eight games left after a 1-0 win at Sunderland, marking a record 25 wins out of 30 matches. Manager Ferguson emphasized focusing on upcoming games, starting with the derby against Manchester City, and highlighted the team's strong recent form with 50 points from the last 18 games. Injuries to Rafael, Anderson, and goalkeeper David De Gea occurred at Sunderland, prompting expected squad changes for the upcoming FA Cup quarter-final replay against Chelsea. Returning players Rooney, Welbeck, and Cleverley were rested at Sunderland, while Giggs, Hernandez, and others are available for selection. Ferguson praised the team's determined defending and courage in a challenging match against Sunderland.

The passage discusses Google's tax payments and related debates. Mr. Schmidt stated that Google paid £10 million in UK corporate taxes from 2006 to 2011 and that the company complies with all legal tax requirements. He emphasized that tax payments are not optional and that any changes in tax amounts depend on government legislation. Margaret Hodge, head of a Parliamentary committee, proposed forming a new committee to secretly oversee major companies' tax arrangements to prevent tax avoidance. Google, criticized for routing UK sales through Ireland to reduce UK tax liabilities, has faced scrutiny alongside other multinationals. The EU has agreed to address tax avoidance via automatic information exchange among tax authorities. Mr. Schmidt advocated that corporate taxes should be based on where economic activity occurs, called for international tax reform, and stressed that politicians, not companies, should set tax rules to create a clearer, simpler system.

The regulator NHS Improvement urges faster progress in reducing the NHS agency staff bill, which was £3.6bn last year. A spending cap introduced in October has saved £600m by limiting agencies to charging no more than 55% above normal shift rates for most staff, excluding senior managers. Despite promising progress, NHS trusts remain 10% behind targets. The data excludes NHS "bank" staff and overtime pay. Concerns persist over excessive agency rates, with reports of some trusts being quoted rates far exceeding the cap, such as £130/hour for a surgeon when the cap is £76. NHS Improvement plans to publish performance league tables and details of top-earning agency staff to increase transparency. Chief executive Jim Mackey emphasized the need to reduce costly agency expenditures due to budget constraints.

The passage describes Longford Town Centre as a symbol of Ireland's economic decline following the Celtic Tiger era, with local businesses like Matt O'Brien's men's clothing shop experiencing significant downturns but now beginning to see gradual improvement through diversification. Fianna Fáil criticizes the government for investing €500 million in water meters instead of improving broadband and for the Industrial Development Authority's failure to attract foreign investment to Longford. The government highlights the planned Center Parcs tourism development, expected to create 1,000 jobs by 2019 pending planning approval, as a positive initiative. Local Fine Gael TD James Bannon emphasizes the area's natural attractions and infrastructure as tourism assets. Despite these developments, traders express concerns such as parking fees deterring customers and urge further support to stimulate the local economy. Overall, the Midlands show early signs of economic recovery but require more targeted efforts.

The competition, concluding on 29 May at the same stadium, involves eight teams playing each other twice with the top four qualifying for the play-offs. Key player stats include Warner leading with 294 runs and 12 sixes, De Villiers with 249 runs and 12 sixes, and De Kock holding the highest individual innings score of 108. Leading wicket-takers are McClenaghan (9 wickets), Kumar (8), and Rahman (7). Four current or former England players participate: Eoin Morgan (Sunrisers Hyderabad), Jos Buttler (Mumbai Indians), Sam Billings (Delhi Daredevils), and Kevin Pietersen (Rising Pune Supergiants). The passage also lists fixtures from 25 April to 22 May, followed by the play-offs: Qualifier 1 (24 May), Eliminator (25 May), Qualifier 2 (27 May), and the Final (29 May).

Since 2013, plastic bag usage has increased by 200 million, causing environmental problems due to their non-recyclable nature and littering. To address this, England will introduce a 5p charge on plastic bags starting in October to encourage reuse. Similar charges in Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland have successfully reduced bag usage, and campaigners hope England's charge will have the same positive environmental impact.

The passage reports that strong winds caused significant disruptions across Wales, including part of a school roof being torn off in Rhosgadfan, Gwynedd, power outages affecting hundreds of homes, train delays with speed restrictions between Llandudno Junction and Holyhead, and cancellations of six Irish Ferries sailings between Holyhead and Dublin. A yellow wind warning was in effect until midnight Friday, the day experiencing high wind gusts notably at Mona, Anglesey. The National Trust closed Erddig Hall and Chirk Castle due to high winds. While evening saw lifted restrictions on major bridges like the A55 Britannia Bridge and M48 Severn Bridge, ongoing windy conditions prompted the postponement of Rhyl's Boxing Day Dip to December 27th. Friday also marked a busy travel day due to the Christmas getaway and workweek end.

Michael B. Jordan expressed excitement about reuniting with director Ryan Coogler for a new film, though he did not specify his role. He looked forward to working with co-stars Lupita Nyong'o, an Oscar winner for 12 Years a Slave, and Chadwick Boseman, known for Black Panther in Captain America: Civil War. Jordan previously played the Human Torch in the Fantastic Four reboot. Nyong'o appeared as Maz Kanata in Star Wars: The Force Awakens. The film Black Panther is set for release in February 2018.

The Alexandra Palace theatre, founded in 1875 and currently unused, is set to be restored for theatrical performances, cinema screenings, comedy, and live music. The adjacent BBC studios will also be refurbished as part of a larger £26.6m east wing restoration project aimed at transforming Alexandra Palace into a cultural destination. The glazed east court will be converted into a public and exhibition space. Funding includes £18.8m from the Heritage Lottery Fund, £6.8m from Haringey Council, and a £1m fundraising commitment by Alexandra Park and Palace Charitable Trust, with the theatre's reopening planned for 2018.

The former Manchester City player, aged 30, earned 61 caps for England since his 2009 debut and participated in two World Cups and two European Championships, playing only three minutes at Euro 2016. He is England's most capped Under-21 player with 46 appearances since 2004 and scored his sole international goal in a 5-0 win over Moldova during the 2014 World Cup qualifiers. Milner expressed support for Sam Allardyce, the players, staff, and fans following a common-sense decision.

Marcy Smith's family home in Glovertown, Newfoundland and Labrador, was destroyed by a rapidly spreading fire started by rubbish burned in their wood stove, which her fire alarm failed to detect. Woken by her son David, who noticed the flames while on FaceTime with his father, the family escaped wearing only pyjamas, but their dog and cats perished. The community has since supported them with donations. Mrs. Smith praised her son for saving her and her daughter, emphasizing his heroic actions despite his young age.

The energy drinks company was reportedly considering a £200m bid for West Ham United. Sullivan and Gold acquired a majority stake in the club in 2010, valuing it at £105m, and currently own over 85%. Since the club's move to London Stadium, takeover interest from Qatari and Chinese groups has been noted. Sullivan previously mentioned the potential sale of a minority stake to clear debts but planned for ownership to remain within their families.

The passage describes an awards ceremony distinct from the Oscars, featuring fan-voted categories like best kiss and best shirtless performance, which Zac Efron won again. The Fault in Our Stars was the night's biggest winner, taking best movie, best female performance (Shailene Woodley), best kiss, and the Trailblazer Award. Other notable winners included Bradley Cooper (best male performance for American Sniper), Channing Tatum (best comedic performance for 22 Jump Street), and Meryl Streep (best villain for Into the Woods). Kevin Hart won the comedic genius award, dedicating it to his children, while Robert Downey Jr received the Generation Award, joined by his Avengers co-stars on stage. The event also showcased previews of upcoming summer films such as Pitch Perfect 2, Trainwreck, and Marvel's Ultron.

Smith, a 21-year-old player loaned from the Dons to Dundee United in July, has scored five goals this season. He debuted for Aberdeen in 2012, scoring four goals in 89 appearances. St Mirren boss Jack Ross praised Smith as a valuable, mature addition who strengthens their attacking options. Currently bottom of the Championship, St Mirren will host Falkirk on Saturday.

Northumberland County Council announced that warmer weather has allowed Jetpatcher machines to begin repairing potholes, aiming to fill 145 daily over the next four months. Additional staff will also address drainage repairs and clear gutters damaged by heavy rain.

In December 2016, six Wood Group contractors working on EnQuest's Thistle platform off Shetland were exposed to low levels of naturally occurring radioactive material (NORM) during shutdown pipework activities. The workers, including rigging supervisor Steve Innes, reported being exposed without proper personal protective equipment due to delayed notification of the hazard. EnQuest stated the exposure was below reportable limits to the Health and Safety Executive (HSE) and that additional safety measures were implemented after investigation. Wood Group emphasized its commitment to employee safety and medical assessments following the incident. The Unite union criticized the handling of the situation, calling for transparency. The HSE acknowledged awareness but did not launch an investigation as the incident was not reportable under current regulations. Mr Innes expressed concerns about long-term health effects and alleged failure of duty of care by EnQuest.

The Asian Civilisation Museum (ACM) purchased a bronze sculpture of Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari for $650,000 in 2007 from the New York dealer Art of the Past, whose manager later admitted to selling stolen Indian antiquities. The sculpture is believed to have been stolen from a Shiva temple in Tamil Nadu, India. Following a request from India's Archaeological Survey of India (ASI) and discussions between the ASI and Singapore's National Heritage Board, ACM decided to return the sculpture. Although there is no definitive proof of theft, ACM acted on the dealer’s confession of handling looted objects. The museum plans to seek legal compensation for the fraud and stated that none of the other 29 objects bought from the dealer are suspected stolen.

A magnitude-4.8 earthquake struck 35km north of Lucca, Italy, at a depth of 15.5km, felt as far as Milan, Florence, Bologna, and Modena. There were no immediate reports of injuries or damage, but power and phone lines were cut in Garfagnana, the quake's epicenter, where schools were evacuated as a precaution. Italy, prone to seismic activity, experienced aftershocks and recalls a deadly 2009 L'Aquila quake that killed nearly 300 people. The 2009 event led to manslaughter convictions for officials who had downplayed the risk ahead of the quake, contributing to many deaths as residents stayed indoors following their advice. This recent tremor was described as medium-strong and shallow, typical for the region.

Austin Grant from Sheffield, initially doubtful about South Yorkshire's climate for growing fruit, has finally seen successful results, expressing great joy, although the fruit is still attached to the plant and not yet ripe.

Rockstar has delayed the release of the latest open-world adventure game from 27 January to 24 March to allow extra testing and polish. They emphasized the decision was made in the best interest of the game and fans. Online heists will launch on consoles before the PC release. New PC screenshots showcase higher detail with 1080p at 60fps, up to 4K resolution, and triple monitor support. Minimum PC specifications have also been released. The previous Grand Theft Auto V set a record as the fastest-selling entertainment product, earning $1 billion within three days of its 2013 release.

A 76-year-old artist, previously shortlisted in 1991 and longlisted three times, won the £25,000 John Moores Painting Prize at Liverpool's Walker Art Gallery with his painting Squint (19). The work, about 7ft (2.1m) high, depicts a leper squint—holes in medieval churches for excluded individuals to view services—and is part of a larger series. Judge Ansel Krut praised it as extraordinary and subtle, likening it to a tone poem that evokes sympathy. The artist plans to use the prize money to buy quality art materials. Established in 1957, the biennial John Moores Painting Prize is among Britain's oldest art awards, with notable past winners including David Hockney, Peter Doig, and patron Sir Peter Blake.

The pro-government newspapers Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit were attacked early Thursday night by masked assailants who fired gunshots, shattering windows and causing a fire at Yeni Safak's offices. No casualties occurred, and firefighters extinguished the blaze quickly. Police secured both sites, found numerous bullet casings, and are searching for the attackers. The two papers support President Erdogan's AK Party. No group has claimed responsibility. Previously, pro-government protesters attacked the Hurriyet daily for alleged misquoting of Erdogan.

A 24-year-old former Burton player, currently under contract with the Stags, will join Marcus Bignot's Mariners on a free transfer starting 1 January. He spent the first half of the season on loan at Crawley, where he scored three goals in 23 appearances, becoming Bignot's first signing for the team.

The passage discusses Arsène Wenger’s comments on England manager Gareth Southgate and Arsenal players. Wenger, whose contract runs until summer, praises Southgate’s growing experience and competency amid speculation linking Wenger to the England job. Southgate, aiming for a permanent role, faces upcoming matches against Scotland and Spain.
