Wenger also addresses player matters at Arsenal, revealing plans to offer a new contract to 21-year-old right-back Hector Bellerin amid transfer rumors, emphasizing his long-term future at the club. Additionally, Wenger notes midfielder Aaron Ramsey will miss one or two more games due to a hamstring injury.

A local man working at Fruehauf on Houghton Road fell from a cherry picker at around 13:45 GMT on Thursday. Lincolnshire Police and the Health and Safety Executive are conducting a joint investigation, with the company fully cooperating.

Transport Minister Humza Yousaf announced a new charter arrangement to resolve a prolonged dispute over seafarers' pay on two freight vessels serving the Northern Isles. The RMT union claimed some crew were paid less than £4 an hour. The charter change will transfer contracted services from Seatruck back to operator Serco Northlink starting next month. Seatruck had argued the national minimum wage did not apply to many non-UK resident crew, and declined Serco's offers to bridge and backdate pay. The new agreement will ensure all crew are paid at least the minimum wage. Serco Northlink holds a six-year, £243 million contract awarded in 2012 to operate ferries and cargo boats on Scottish government-subsidised routes to the Northern Isles.

Ken Dickie, 64, died in hospital six days after an incident at Rockley Park, Poole. Jamie Mitchell, 35, admitted intervening in an argument between Dickie and his mother, Samantha Mitchell, with whom Dickie had a strained relationship. On 7 May, after drinking at a holiday park bar, Jamie Mitchell and Dickie had a confrontation outside. Jamie pleaded guilty to common assault, and both he and his mother admitted attempting to pervert the course of justice by lying about the events to police. They will be sentenced on 6 February.

Rod Temperton, a prolific British songwriter and keyboardist, died in London at 66 after a brief battle with cancer. Known as "The Invisible Man" for his low profile, Temperton gained fame in the 1970s with disco band Heatwave, writing hits like "Boogie Nights." He later wrote iconic songs for Michael Jackson's albums Off The Wall ("Off The Wall," "Rock With You," "Burn This Disco Out") and Thriller ("Thriller," "Baby Be Mine," "The Lady in My Life"), contributing to Thriller being the best-selling US album ever. His work was also recorded by artists like Anita Baker and Aretha Franklin. Temperton won a Grammy in 1990 and was twice Oscar-nominated. Tributes from celebrities including Nile Rodgers, LaToya Jackson, Mark Ronson, and Chaka Khan praised his songwriting genius. Born in Cleethorpes, Temperton attributed his musical influence to listening to the radio as a child. His family has requested privacy following his death.

A team including Swansea University researchers discovered over 450 ancient, possibly 2,000-year-old geometrical earthworks, or geoglyphs, in Acre state, western Brazilian Amazon, previously hidden by dense rainforest. These structures were likely ritual gathering places rather than villages or fortifications, as few artefacts were found and their layout suggests non-defensive use. Unlike other global ritual sites, these geoglyphs were constructed within taller vegetation, making them not visible above the canopy. The research challenges the idea that pre-European Amazon forests were untouched, showing humans influenced biodiversity over 6,000 years by concentrating valuable plants like palms, resembling a "prehistoric supermarket." This ancient agroforestry legacy may still persist in Acre’s forests today.

Australian 21-year-old Nick Kyrgios, ranked a career-high 12th, defeated world number 29 Sam Querrey 6-4 6-4 in 53 minutes to reach the second round. Fresh off winning the Japan Open, Kyrgios is nearing the top 10 but admitted to feeling tired and less vocal during the match due to travel fatigue and poor rest. He also referenced last year's Shanghai Masters, where he was fined $1,500 for a foul-mouthed outburst calling the tournament a "circus".

The passage discusses calls from scientists and charities for the Welsh government to extend the HPV vaccination program to boys to protect against rising cases of head and neck cancers linked to HPV. Currently, HPV vaccines are given to girls aged 12-13 to prevent cervical cancer, with 85% vaccination coverage since the 2008 school program. Experts note an increase in head and neck cancers, mostly affecting younger men who are often non-smokers. Organizations like Tenovus Cancer Care and Cardiff University's HPV research team urge the government to act proactively by vaccinating boys, while the Welsh government awaits advice from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation before making changes.

Jak Trueman, a 15-year-old boy from West Calder High School, suffered from a rare blood cancer called gamma delta T-cell lymphoma. Diagnosed in August, he documented his battle and positive attitude on a Facebook page, Jak's Journey, which gained over 28,000 Likes. Despite his illness, Jak briefly attended a prom held in his honor, where he received awards including the Bronze Duke of Edinburgh Award and the Kerry MacGregor Memorial Trophy. In January, doctors discovered his cancer had spread, leading to a decision to stop treatment. Jak and his family shared many personal moments online and received visits from sports players and performers. Following the terminal diagnosis, they encouraged donations to Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research. Further fundraising continued with a charity football match at Livingston FC's Energy Assets Arena. Jak passed away shortly after his brief prom attendance.

In a closely contested Group D match with few clear chances, Egypt edged Uganda 1-0 thanks to an 89th-minute goal by Abdallah El Said, assisted by Mohamed Salah. Despite Uganda's Joseph Ochaya having a goal disallowed for offside and a strong defensive effort, including impressive saves from goalkeeper Denis Onyango, they failed to score. The win keeps Egypt in contention for top spot and a quarter-final place against Ghana, who had earlier defeated Mali 1-0 to secure their advancement. Uganda, participating in their first tournament since 1978, were eliminated. The match featured several substitutions, fouls, and missed attempts on a deteriorating pitch, with key defensive actions from both sides but a largely uneventful first half until the late decisive goal.

Lancashire County Council plans to develop a new railway station in Skelmersdale, selecting land on the former Glenburn Sports College and Skelmersdale College sites following a Network Rail study. The sports college closed in August, and Skelmersdale College's campus is unused. The town’s original station closed in 1956, and Skelmersdale, designated a new town in 1961, remains one of the largest towns in northwest England without a station. The council, partnering with Merseytravel and West Lancashire Borough Council, aims for two direct trains per hour to Liverpool. The preferred site offers space for expansion, good highway access, and connectivity. The council will begin acquiring the land to move the project forward.
A man in his late 40s was arrested at a warehouse near Ashbourne on Saturday morning, where police discovered an elaborate grow house containing plants.

A 28-year-old woman in Hamelin, Lower Saxony, was found seriously injured on a pavement after being dragged by the neck through several streets. She underwent emergency surgery and was flown to a specialist clinic. Her 38-year-old ex-partner from nearby Bad Muender, both German citizens of Kurdish origin, later handed himself in to authorities and is now in custody. The motive for the attack remains unclear, and police have secured the area and are seeking witnesses.

The study analyzed 4,600 Australian workers to test the "reticent female" theory about women being less likely to ask for pay rises and found no evidence supporting it—women ask for raises as often as men but are 25% less likely to receive them. By comparing full-time males and females and controlling for factors like employer size, industry, parenting status, and qualifications, the research concluded that discrimination against women may exist in pay rise outcomes. Younger men and women under 40 showed equal rates of asking for and receiving raises, suggesting shifting negotiation behaviors among younger women. Researchers highlighted that anecdotal beliefs about women not asking for pay increases are unfounded, and the findings imply some element of gender discrimination in pay decisions.

Oxford City Council has been searching for new burial sites for many years, spending money mostly on investigating potential locations but finding none suitable due to size, ground conditions, water tables, or legal restrictions. Two cemeteries in Wolvercote and Botley still have space but are expected to be full by 2018 and 2021. Once full, only reopening family plots, using reserved plots, and interring ashes will be possible. The last expansion of burial space in Oxford occurred in 1932.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival (HebCelt) will take place in Stornoway, Isle of Lewis, from 19 to 22 July, featuring acts like The Waterboys, Imelda May, and Dougie MacLean. Visitors can use a new app offering augmented reality to access online content such as videos and band interviews via signs and posters on-site. This feature enhances the festival experience and allows people worldwide to engage with the event, access updated information, buy tickets, and enjoy its atmosphere remotely.

The 10-year-old Irish-bred horse Many Clouds collapsed and died after narrowly winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham. Veterinary staff treated him, but he was pronounced dead due to a severe pulmonary haemorrhage, a rare and sudden condition affecting horses without underlying health issues. Despite having previously exhibited post-race ataxia symptoms such as overheating and wobbling, Many Clouds had no such symptoms during this race. He was a successful racehorse, having won the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014, and was described as the "horse of a lifetime" by trainer Oliver Sherwood. The British Horseracing Authority acknowledged the rarity of such incidents and emphasized the sport’s commitment to understanding and preventing them.

A defendant named Davina Ayrton, formerly known as David Ayrton and now 34, was charged with raping a 15-year-old girl she met in a Portsmouth garage in 2004. Ayrton denied the charge and was remanded in custody to a male prison due to risks if released on bail. The court heard Ayrton, who has learning difficulties and had attempted suicide, changed her name in 2012 and had not undergone physical or medical gender changes. The victim, who had been drinking lightly, recalled being attacked while two others slept nearby. Ayrton disclosed the attack in 2014 to a care home worker. Sentencing was scheduled for 4 March at Portsmouth Crown Court.

The Serb doubles team lost 6-4, 6-4 to Brazilians Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares in Rio, a day after Novak Djokovic was eliminated from the singles by Juan Martin del Potro. Djokovic, the world number one and 12-time Grand Slam winner, had a surprising third-round defeat at Wimbledon to Sam Querrey but later won his 30th Masters title in Toronto before the Olympics.

The event in Carrbridge, Cairngorms will feature over 20 competitors from Scotland, England, Ireland, continental Europe, Canada, and the US. Participants must use only chainsaws to carve logs into animal and human shapes. Last year's winner, Pete Bowsher from Moffat, will return to defend his title and the Claymore Trophy.

Webb, a 27-year-old Welsh rugby player capped 16 times, has been recovering from a serious foot injury sustained in a World Cup warm-up match in September. He is currently in a pre-season phase and expects to return to fitness in time for the Six Nations starting in February, potentially earlier than initially planned. Webb has renewed his national dual contract with the Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union, choosing to stay with his home region club where he debuted in 2007, aiming to maintain his position for the national team. Wales will begin their Six Nations campaign against Ireland on 7 February.

Two men carrying backpacks near the US-Canada border east of Sumas, Washington, were stopped by US border agents while attempting to smuggle 58 pounds (26 kg) of ecstasy from Canada to San Francisco. One man, Jeffrey Laviolette, was arrested immediately; the other, Nathan Hall, fired a weapon and fled but was later apprehended in British Columbia. A California driver’s license with Hall’s photo but another name was found in the backpacks. Subsequently, a woman, Kali Henifin, and her boyfriend, Ryan Lambert, were arrested; they were allegedly involved in transporting the drugs and were monitoring police communications during the incident. All five face conspiracy, possession, and distribution charges. The location is a known drug and firearm smuggling route, with such prosecutions common in the area.

The NSPCC's Childline reported counseling over 4,500 children experiencing online abuse in the past year, nearly double the 2,400 cases in 2011-12, with actual numbers likely higher. Children as young as seven described being tormented and afraid to attend school due to online bullying, which causes widespread misery and humiliation. Childline's president, Dame Esther Rantzen, emphasized that cyber-bullying follows children beyond school, making adult intervention crucial. The report coincides with Anti-Bullying Week, led by the Anti Bullying Alliance, which collaborates with parents, schools, and organizations to tackle the issue. A child’s testimony highlighted the emotional impact of online harassment and the difficulty of seeking help despite parental advice.

The passage details tensions surrounding a recent UN Security Council resolution condemning Israeli settlement construction in occupied West Bank and East Jerusalem, viewed as illegal under international law. The US abstained from vetoing the resolution, angering Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who accused the White House of drafting it—an assertion denied by the US. In response, Israel took diplomatic reprisals and initially planned to approve new settlement homes but postponed the vote at Netanyahu's office request to avoid worsening US relations before Secretary of State John Kerry's upcoming speech on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. Kerry aims to clarify the US position amid Israeli criticism. Meanwhile, Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas welcomed the resolution as supportive of a peace conference planned in France in January to end the occupation.

The passage details celebrations and tributes marking Queen Elizabeth II's 90th birthday. In a BBC interview, Prince William praised the Queen as a "guiding example" of a good monarch, acknowledging criticisms of his own royal duties but emphasizing his serious commitment and gradual assumption of responsibilities. Events included the Queen and Duke of Edinburgh visiting Windsor's Royal Mail office for the postal service's 500th anniversary, opening a new bandstand with local schoolchildren, and unveiling a plaque for The Queen's Walkway celebrating her record-breaking reign. Ten commemorative stamps featuring four generations of the Royal Family were issued. The Queen planned to light a beacon initiating over 900 beacons nationwide. Political leaders like Prime Minister David Cameron expressed admiration, while the republican group Republic criticized the extensive media coverage as excessive and unbalanced. US President Barack Obama and First Lady Michelle Obama were scheduled to lunch with the Queen at Windsor Castle following the celebrations.

West Ham United defeated Cheltenham Town 2-0 in an EFL Cup match. After a strong start from Cheltenham, West Ham gained control before half-time with quick goals from Diafra Sakho and Andre Ayew. Cheltenham, unchanged from a recent league loss, performed respectfully but failed to seriously challenge West Ham's goalkeeper. West Ham made seven changes following Premier League defeats and had chances to extend their lead, with Cheltenham's defense and goalkeeper making notable saves. The win ended League Two's participation in the EFL Cup. The match featured multiple substitutions, fouls, and attempts on goal from both sides, but no further goals were scored.

Hospital radiographer Aidan McNicholl, 36, died in a collision on the A5 at Cerrigydrudion caused by Andreas Werner, 46, who failed to see the motorcyclist while turning his VW Transporter. Werner pleaded guilty to causing death by careless driving, was fined £1,000, and banned from driving in the UK for two years. The victim's family did not seek a jail sentence, viewing the crash as a momentary lapse, and Werner expressed remorse without explanation for the incident.

Imran Khawaja, a 27-year-old British jihadist from Southall, west London, traveled to Syria in January last year, joining the Islamic State-affiliated group Rayat al Tawheed. There, he actively created and shared propaganda videos depicting jihadist life and appeals for donations, portraying fighting as adventurous and noble, despite also producing gruesome content, including images of violence and executions. Under the alias Abu Daigham al-Britani, Khawaja became one of the most public British fighters in Syria. Monitored by MI5, he attempted to return secretly to the UK last June, faking his death online and enlisting the help of his cousin, Tahir Bhatti. Authorities intercepted him on arrival at Dover, leading to prosecution. Khawaja, considered highly dangerous, was held in a high-security unit and admitted multiple offenses, while Bhatti pleaded guilty to assisting him. A charge of soliciting murder against Khawaja remains on file.

Jackson, 22, scored four goals in 36 appearances last season for Wrexham, who finished eighth. He is Barnsley's third signing for next season, joining ahead of their League One play-off final. Barnsley's caretaker boss Paul Heckingbottom praised Jackson's pace and playing style. Jackson declined a contract offer from Wrexham to join Barnsley.

National Trust volunteers have been clearing sealed detergent bottles washing up at Poldhu Cove and nearby Cornish coves, believed to have come from a container lost overboard by the ship MV Blue Ocean during stormy weather near Land's End in May. Although some bottles have leaked, their exact origin is unconfirmed. Conservationists, including Cornwall Wildlife Trust, express concern over potential harm to sensitive marine life from the detergent. Authorities, including Cornwall Council and the Maritime and Coastguard Agency, are monitoring the situation, advising the public to keep clear of the bottles and not to attempt recovery.

A crash occurred around 14:00 on the A9 north of Berriedale in Caithness, causing minor injuries to several people. The road was closed, with diversions via the A897 Helmsdale to Melvich road, and Police Scotland is investigating.

Dervite, a 28-year-old French centre-back, made 14 appearances last season to help Bolton Wanderers finish second in League One and achieve promotion. Since joining from Charlton in 2014, he has made 83 appearances in all competitions. Manager Phil Parkinson praised his important contribution late in the season. Dervite has signed a new contract, joining teammates David Wheater, Gary Madine, and Jem Karacan in committing to Bolton following their promotion to the Championship.

The Lib Dems and Labour initially cooperated in the House of Lords to oppose the government on EU citizens' rights and parliamentary approval of a Brexit deal. However, this alliance broke down when MPs rejected related amendments: Lib Dems insisted on them, while Labour deferred to the Commons. Lib Dems accused Labour of supporting a hard Brexit and giving false hope to voters, while Labour dismissed Lib Dems' actions as grandstanding for campaign purposes. Despite broader history of opposition cooperation on issues like education and housing, Labour anticipates ongoing tensions with Lib Dems, though both parties’ leaderships intend to maintain professional relations.

The passage discusses how defence has become a low priority in the current UK election, with public and political interest focused more on issues like the economy, the NHS, and immigration. Despite increasing global threats, the UK is reducing its military capabilities, including cuts to the Army, Navy, and Air Force, leading to capability gaps such as lacking Maritime Patrol Aircraft. UK defence spending has fallen from 4th to 6th in the world and is likely to drop below NATO’s 2% GDP target, with further budget cuts expected amid broader austerity measures. While the Conservatives commit to replacing Trident and modestly increasing equipment budgets, other parties show varied positions on nuclear deterrence and military spending. The upcoming Strategic Defence Review will reassess key programmes like Trident amid financial constraints. Meanwhile, new high-cost assets like aircraft carriers face operational challenges due to personnel shortages and limited equipment deployment. Overall, the UK risks having advanced military technology but insufficient resources to fully utilize it, undermining its historical global defence role.

Barcelona denies any wrongdoing in Neymar's transfer, asserting their tax payments were appropriate despite ongoing investigations and allegations of undisclosed costs beyond the reported £48.6m fee. The club paid a total of £106.8m for Neymar, including transfer fees, wages, agent fees, and a recent additional tax payment of €13.55m to clarify any tax-related ambiguities. Former president Sandro Rosell resigned amid related accusations but denies misconduct. A Spanish judge allowed the investigation to continue, with no confirmation yet if the case will be closed following Barcelona's supplementary payment. Neymar has contributed seven league goals and three Champions League goals this season.

Michael Luciw, 27, died as a passenger in a van hit by a Mazda Premacy driven the wrong way by Albert Kenneth Newman, who also died, near Kegworth, Leicestershire. Luciw’s family urged regular driving tests for elderly drivers, citing slowed reactions with age, while Age UK emphasized supporting older people to drive safely for as long as possible. Currently, UK drivers over 70 must self-assess their health every three years to renew licenses, without mandatory medical or driving tests. The DVLA states it has no plans to impose age-based restrictions, asserting older drivers are not more likely to cause serious accidents. Following the crash, calls have been made for stricter testing of retired drivers to prevent similar incidents.

The passage discusses controversies surrounding transvaginal mesh implants used to treat incontinence in women. Two patients resigned from the original review group in protest over a perceived diluted final report, prompting independent expert Professor Alison Britton to examine the review process and recommend future lessons. The final report advised against routine use of these procedures for pelvic organ prolapse, urged offering patients multiple treatment options with full information, and called for mandatory adverse event reporting. Despite campaigners’ calls for a ban, the government stated it lacks the authority to prohibit the procedures, which lies with UK regulatory bodies. Tracey Gillies, the review’s chairwoman in its final stages, apologized for failing to unify panel members amid strong opposition and protests from affected women. Several members, including two patients and a consultant, quit citing dissatisfaction with the report’s handling. Over 20,000 women in Scotland have undergone mesh implants in the past 20 years, with some experiencing serious complications; over 400 women are pursuing legal action against health boards and manufacturers.

Laura Muir, 23, broke Laura McColgan's 25-year-old British indoor 5000m record by 14 seconds at Glasgow’s Emirates Arena with a time of 14:49.12. McColgan expressed excitement but raised concerns about the race's compliance with UK Athletics criteria, noting it was not a genuine race since Muir was the only competitor completing 5K and questioned drug testing procedures. British Athletics confirmed the record is expected to be ratified, clarifying no doping control is required for records at events without it. McColgan praised Muir’s potential, estimating she could run as fast as 14:30 and compete at the world level. She also likened Muir’s solo effort to her own record-breaking race 25 years prior. Muir previously set the British 1500m record and competed in the 2016 Olympic final.

Jung won the equestrian event aboard Sam, a late replacement horse. France's Astier Nicolas took silver, and American Phillip Dutton won bronze. Britain's William Fox-Pitt finished 12th despite a faultless final show-jumping round, having led after dressage but falling behind due to time penalties in cross-country. Fox-Pitt was competing just 10 months after a serious fall. Ireland's Jonty Evans finished ninth.

Andy Murray, 30, defeated 29th seed Fabio Fognini in a four-set match (6-2, 4-6, 6-1, 7-5) lasting two hours and 39 minutes to reach the last 16 of the tournament for the 11th time. Despite Fognini having five set points to push the match to a fifth set, Murray won five consecutive games to seal victory. Murray will face Benoit Paire in the fourth round. Earlier, fellow Briton Johanna Konta also advanced to the second week with a 6-4, 6-1 win over Maria Sakkari. The match was tense and affected by fading light, with Fognini showing moments of skill but also frustration, including a penalty for obscenity. Murray managed to overcome challenges including double faults and a slight decline in movement, expressing satisfaction at progressing and looking forward to improving ahead of his next match.

Paramedics responded to a sudden death at Joe's Bar in Dungiven on 6 October 2014 at 06:00 BST. Police found patrons still present, with till receipts indicating alcohol sales until 04:49 BST. The court ordered the bar's closure for three months. Colleen O'Neill, the license holder, was charged with two counts of allowing liquor consumption outside licensed hours and fined £3,000; James Thomas faced one similar charge and was fined £1,000. The defense acknowledged poor adherence to licensing laws, and the judge condemned O'Neill's record as appalling, expressing concern over the inability to impose a custodial sentence.

Mike Nesbitt, launching the Ulster Unionist Party's manifesto titled 'Real Partnership', emphasized partnership over domination and framed the election as a referendum on the handling of the Renewable Heat Incentive scandal. Despite controversy over his preference to work with the SDLP rather than Sinn Féin post-election, Nesbitt stood by his remarks, highlighting strong local support and unity within his party despite differing vote transfer strategies. The manifesto calls for actions including addressing healthcare waiting lists, increasing PSNI numbers, prioritizing infrastructure projects, supporting the LGBT community, ensuring no group is disadvantaged by Brexit, and cleaning up Stormont by tackling incompetence, arrogance, cronyism, and corruption. Nesbitt aims for these issues to overshadow the controversy surrounding his comments.

Justice Minister Claire Sugden announced that a motion will be presented to the Northern Ireland assembly seeking approval to grant automatic pardons for men convicted of abolished sexual offences, aligning with similar plans in England and Wales known as 'Turing's Law.' The law allows both posthumous pardons for deceased men and pardons for living gay and bisexual men who were convicted. Sugden secured executive agreement to request the assembly pass this legislative consent motion to ensure equal treatment across the UK. The motion aims to address past injustices swiftly and will be considered by the assembly soon.

Laura Muir, a 23-year-old from Kinross, set a new Scottish 1500m record with a time of 4:19.12, finishing second behind Kenyan Faith Kipyegon. This time surpassed Yvonne Murray's 1994 Scottish record and placed Muir second on the British all-time list behind Zola Budd. Muir, who also holds the Scottish mile record and finished fifth at last year's World Championships, aims to qualify for the Rio Olympics at upcoming British trials. She began her season with an 800m win in France and balances her training with veterinary studies, having just completed her fourth year of vet school.
The passage presents pictures from 26 beaches in Scotland recognized for having the highest water quality.

The Met Police barrister Richard Horwell QC argued that Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi had no personal motive to kill Alexander Litvinenko, suggesting the Russian state likely sponsored the plot due to multiple possible motives, including Litvinenko's defection and personal attacks on Vladimir Putin. Litvinenko was poisoned in London in 2006 by drinking tea containing radioactive polonium-210 during a meeting with the suspects and died nearly three weeks later. The use of polonium indicates Russian state involvement, though Putin's direct role is unconfirmed. Horwell highlighted that Litvinenko was poisoned twice, suffered greatly, and that the public risk from polonium exposure remains unknown. The suspects left a trail of polonium and failed to counter scientific evidence. Attempts to extradite Kovtun and Lugovoi for murder trials have failed, and the inquiry noted these men remain in Russia, with Kovtun criticized for not providing evidence.

Steve Smith, 26, has been appointed captain of Australia's one-day and Twenty20 cricket teams, succeeding Michael Clarke, 34, who retired after the Ashes defeat to England. David Warner, 28, is named vice-captain despite past disciplinary issues, reflecting his maturity and leadership development. Selector Rod Marsh praised Smith's talent and suitability for the role, noting Smith's previous Test captaincy experience and strong batting record. Smith and Warner will lead the limited-overs matches following the final Ashes Test starting August 20.

The passage details Mr. Farron's position on LGBT-plus rights amid questions about his personal beliefs on homosexual sex. Although he repeatedly avoided directly stating whether he believes homosexual sex is a sin, he emphasized his strong commitment to LGBT-plus rights and equality. Farron highlighted that defending equal marriage is a top priority and expressed a desire to extend marital rights to transgender people, noting issues like the spousal veto that limits transgender marital equality. He explained that his 2007 vote against the Equality Bill was due to concerns about protecting individual liberties connected to an amendment proposed by the Lib Dems, but maintained his support for equal legal access regardless of sexuality.

French-based Sanofi closed its Fawdon drug manufacturing plant in 2015, resulting in 450 job losses. Accord Healthcare is now reopening the facility for pharmaceutical production, aiming to rehire many former Sanofi employees. The investment is expected to positively impact the area, strengthening Newcastle and the North East's reputation in the science and healthcare sector. Accord Healthcare is a global pharmaceutical company producing over 130 products distributed to around 60 countries.

Richard Ellis is leaving the council at the end of his contract on Friday, while Ciaran Monaghan and Ewan Sutherland are departing through a voluntary redundancy and early retirement scheme. Ellis served as interim director of corporate governance and acting deputy chief executive; Monaghan headed the chief executive's office; Sutherland led human resources and customer services. Opposition leader Stephen Flynn viewed these departures as a sign of the council's struggle to retain senior staff and anticipated more to follow. Council chief executive Angela Scott expressed gratitude for their dedication and professionalism.

The English rider experienced a crash at this year's TT and faced ongoing mechanical issues with the Fireblade bike. Although initially announcing he was quitting road racing, he clarified he has no plans to race on Hondas this year but hasn't given up racing altogether. He skipped the North West 200 after his teammate's crash and will not compete in the Ulster Grand Prix, as the team withdrew him due to the bike's lack of competitiveness. He described the TT as a disaster, mentioned his role as a test rider, and expressed interest in racing classic and unusual motorcycles instead.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of 28 governorships in Nigeria's recent elections, marking the biggest defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since 1999 and following APC leader Muhammadu Buhari's presidential victory over incumbent Goodluck Jonathan. The PDP lost key northern states and areas affected by Boko Haram insurgency but retained some southern strongholds like Rivers State. The APC dominated most northern states and Lagos but did not win any of the five oil-producing states, posing challenges for Buhari regarding militant disruptions and oil revenue. The elections saw some violence but were generally more peaceful than before, indicating Nigeria's democratic progress. The PDP faces a need for introspection and rebuilding after 16 years in power, having suffered from defections, corruption allegations, and failure to address insurgency effectively.

The US-based environmental group Mighty accuses agricultural trader Olam and its main stakeholder, Singapore’s state-owned Temasek, of enabling unsustainable palm oil practices linked to haze-causing fires and deforestation in Indonesia and Gabon. Olam, which sources 99% of its palm oil from third parties and holds less than 1% of the global market, denies the claims, emphasizing its strict "no burn-no peat-no deforestation" sourcing policy. The company recently disclosed its 14 suppliers but acknowledges verifying all suppliers' compliance will take years. Temasek dismisses allegations, stressing governance separation from Olam’s operations and support for no-burn policies. The passage highlights the palm oil industry's broader issues with environmental harm, labor abuses, and challenges in regulating third-party suppliers, while noting tensions between economic benefits and environmental protection. Olam counters assertions about destructive practices in Gabon, asserting responsible and transparent partnerships with the local government.
The restaurant started offering puppy platters following a new law permitting dogs to dine outdoors at restaurants.

Forward Fernando Forestieri is doubtful due to a knee issue, having only appeared as a substitute recently. Striker David Nugent, sidelined with a groin injury, may return after missing the last game. Midfielder Jacob Butterfield aims for a starting spot following his late equalizer as a substitute.

Pakistan lifted its 2012 Supreme Court-imposed ban on YouTube after Google launched a Pakistan-specific version of the platform. The Pakistan Telecommunication Authority directed internet providers to restore access, with the government stating that Google had provided a process for the PTA to request blocking of offending content locally. YouTube emphasized that government removal requests are reviewed against community guidelines and recorded in its Transparency Report. While many young Pakistanis welcomed the ban's end, activists have called for greater transparency regarding the deal between Google and the Pakistani government. The original ban followed protests and deaths caused by an anti-Islamic video uploaded to YouTube.

The passage discusses controversy surrounding Domenico Scala, head of FIFA's Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, ahead of the February 26 election to replace long-time president Sepp Blatter. Scala, who is Swiss-Italian like candidate Gianni Infantino, was previously excused from the 2015 election due to shared nationality with candidate Blatter. Musa Bility, president of the Liberian Football Association, demands Scala's withdrawal by Thursday citing FIFA's rule barring committee members with conflicts of interest, threatening to take the matter to the Court of Arbitration for Sport if not complied with. Scala's spokesman argues no conflict exists for this election, as no incumbent is running and the rule is not in FIFA regulations. Bility seeks clarification on why Scala has not stepped down as he did in 2015. Bility himself was barred from running after failing eligibility and has endorsed candidate Prince Ali, urging African members to support him. The election will feature five candidates—Infantino, Prince Ali, Jerome Champagne, Sheikh Salman, and Tokyo Sexwale—and be decided by FIFA's 209 member associations in Zurich.

Daniel Timbers (29) and Barry Joy (56) died in a flashover explosion at Harford Attachments, Spar Road, shortly after 09:00 BST on Monday while working in a paint-spraying area. Their bodies were removed on Tuesday afternoon. A forensic search at the digger bucket manufacturing company has progressed, with evidence indicating a buildup of toxic fumes ignited to cause a fireball. The Health and Safety Executive is also investigating, with inspectors and electrical safety experts gathering evidence.

Tunisia faced potential expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations (AFCON) after lodging complaints over a controversial penalty awarded against them in the 2015 quarter-final hosted by Equatorial Guinea, which led to tensions with CAF. However, after apologizing, Tunisia was reinstated for the 2017 tournament. Meanwhile, Morocco was initially banned from the 2017 AFCON qualifiers following their refusal to host the 2015 Nations Cup due to Ebola concerns, but the Court of Arbitration for Sport overturned this ban and reduced their fine from $1 million to $50,000. Tunisia’s participation in 2017 was secured after meetings with CAF officials resolved disputes. Tunisia will compete in Group A against Togo, Liberia, and Djibouti, while Morocco will be in Group F with Cape Verde, Libya, and Sao Tome. Tunisia aims for a record thirteenth consecutive AFCON finals appearance.

In the 95th minute of a match at Etihad Stadium, which Chelsea won 3-1, Manchester City players Sergio Aguero and Fernandinho were sent off following a mass fracas. Aguero received a four-match ban for violent conduct, his second this season, while Fernandinho was given a three-match ban due to a clash with Chelsea's Cesc Fabregas, who will face no further action. City manager Pep Guardiola apologized for his team's involvement. Both clubs have until 18:00 GMT on 8 December to respond to the charge.

The passage describes a pilot scheme in Cwm Cynon and Neath, Wales, addressing high cancer invasion rates by focusing on patients suspected of cancer by their GPs but showing no urgent symptoms. Inspired by Danish diagnostic systems that improved cancer survival rates, the scheme allows about 40 GPs to refer such patients directly to diagnostic centers within seven days, aiming for same-day tests. Currently, only 35% of symptomatic patients receive timely diagnoses in Cwm Taf. The new clinic hopes to diagnose cancers earlier, avoid treatment delays, and ultimately improve patient outcomes. If the six-month pilot succeeds, the service will expand across local health boards.

England secured a dominant victory over Pakistan at Old Trafford with a day to spare, leveling the Test series. England declared scores of 589-8 and 173-1 to achieve their second-largest win over Pakistan by runs. Joe Root, promoted to number three, was named man of the match for his 254 and unbeaten 71 runs, along with valuable fielding contributions. Captain Alastair Cook praised Root’s performance, and Coach Trevor Bayliss highlighted Root’s improvement following earlier mistakes. Pakistan struggled on a flat pitch, batting poorly in both innings, leading to criticism of their confidence and shot selection by captain Misbah-ul-Haq. Former England player Geoffrey Boycott praised England’s discipline and quality, predicting they will remain strong throughout the series, which is expected to be tightly contested. Pakistan will next play a tour game before the third Test at Edgbaston.

Head coach Warren Gatland is leading the British and Irish Lions tour in New Zealand, with interim coach Rob Howley as part of his backroom team. Forwards coach McBryde will serve as head coach for Wales for the third time, following his previous leadership on 2009 and 2013 tours. The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) is appointing assistant coaches to support McBryde on the summer tour, with final management team confirmations expected soon. WRU officials believe that the involvement of Welsh coaches in the Lions tour will benefit Welsh rugby by providing valuable development opportunities and inspiring coaches and players through challenging experiences.

Hull City ended a six-game Premier League losing streak with a 2-1 home victory over Southampton. Despite losing two starting strikers, Abel Hernandez and Will Keane, to injuries early on, Hull introduced Robert Snodgrass, whose energy sparked a turnaround. Southampton took an early lead via a Charlie Austin penalty, but Snodgrass scored and assisted a Michael Dawson header in quick succession shortly after halftime. David Marshall made crucial saves to preserve the lead, and Sam Clucas made a last-minute goal-line clearance. The match atmosphere was subdued due to Hull’s poor form and fan dissatisfaction, with attendance low. Managers Mike Phelan (Hull) and Claude Puel (Southampton) acknowledged their teams’ challenges and lessons learned. Hull resumes league play against Sunderland after the international break while Southampton hosts Liverpool.

A fatal crash occurred around 14:15 BST on the B1191 at Thornton near Woodhall Spa, Lincolnshire. The local motorcyclist died, while the tractor driver was uninjured. Lincolnshire Police have not released further details and are seeking witnesses. The B1191 was closed both ways between the B1192 Tattershall Road junction and the A158 Jubilee Way junction.

The passage details Macedonia's political turmoil following the release of covert recordings in 2015, which revealed allegations of abuse of power, vote-rigging, government corruption, wiretapping, and cover-ups of killings. President Ivanov cancelled an investigation into these claims ahead of early elections, aiming to "put an end to the agony," a move condemned by opposition leader Zoran Zaev and EU officials, including EU Enlargement Commissioner Johannes Hahn, who said it threatened Macedonia’s EU prospects and rule of law. Zaev urged protests, accusing the government of corruption and repression, while the government denied the accusations and accused Zaev of trying to destabilize the country.

Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams are set to lead Swansea in Saturday’s match against Bournemouth following Bob Bradley's sacking. Swansea aims to appoint a new manager quickly, with ex-Derby manager Paul Clement the preferred candidate. Curtis emphasized the need for a strong leader to avoid relegation, noting the increased difficulty of returning to the Premier League if demoted. Swansea, promoted to the Premier League in 2011 after rising from near bankruptcy and potential Football League exit, thrived under past managers Roberto Martinez, Brendan Rodgers, and Michael Laudrup, but has since lost its distinctive "Swansea Way" amidst frequent managerial changes and inadequate player replacements. Curtis believes the current squad is capable of avoiding relegation and stresses the importance of understanding the club’s history and the significance of staying in the Premier League for both the club and the local community.

Dagenham & Redbridge, who reached League One in 2010 and the Football League for the first time in 2007 under manager John Still, were relegated to the National League after losing to Leyton Orient. Despite goals from Jamie Cureton and Clevid Dikamona, Armand Gnanduillet’s winner sealed their fate. The Daggers struggled throughout the season with the worst goal difference in League Two, conceding 20 more goals than the previous year and seeing a decline in attacking performance, exemplified by Cureton scoring nine goals compared to 20 in 2014-15. John Still, in his third spell as manager, pledged to help the team regain promotion next season. Leyton Orient, who won the match, remain two points shy of the play-offs following recent managerial changes, with interim manager Andy Hessenthaler emphasizing professionalism and commitment to the fans. Both managers acknowledged organizational and disciplinary issues affected the outcome.

Steven Gerrard, the former Liverpool captain, is set to return to Liverpool as a youth coach in February, marking his first role since retiring as a player in November after a 19-year career. Liverpool manager Jürgen Klopp praised Gerrard’s ambition to become a manager and highlighted his bright future in coaching. Gerrard, who debuted for Liverpool in 1998 and left in 2015 after winning multiple major trophies, had considered managing MK Dons but felt the timing was premature. He is currently working towards his UEFA A coaching licence, necessary for Premier League management.

McManus opened the scoring for Morton on the 15th minute, followed by Ross Forbes' deflected goal to double their lead. Kyle McAusland scored for Alloa before half-time, but additional goals from McManus and Denny Johnstone secured a comfortable victory for Morton.

Ofsted has discovered children being taught in squalid conditions at three illegal schools in Birmingham, which have since been closed with owners under investigation. A wider inspection of 18 unregulated schools, mainly in Muslim communities in the Midlands, suggests these cases are just the "tip of the iceberg," with concerns over child abuse and radicalisation. Legal requirements mandate registration for places teaching children over 20 hours weekly; some part-time "flexi schools" supporting home education operate legally, but others exploit this status to run illegal schools. Sir Michael Wilshaw criticized government officials for providing confusing advice that delayed action. The government has funded six inspectors to investigate illegal schools across all religious groups. The Education Secretary plans prosecutions against such schools, with government consultation on stricter regulations ongoing until mid-January. Illegal school operators face up to 51 weeks in jail.

Lilliard Gin, based at the Born in the Borders visitor centre in Jedburgh, is set to become the region’s first new distillery in nearly 200 years, preceding several whisky distillery proposals in the Scottish Borders. Led by distiller Kate Macinnes, the small-scale operation uses one of the UK's smallest stills and aims to capture local flavors from the Teviot valley’s wild botanicals, reflecting the region’s terroir. John Henderson of Born in the Borders highlights Lilliard Gin’s alignment with local sourcing and its natural fit alongside the Scottish Borders Brewery. The gin is named after Lilliard, a legendary Borders heroine linked to the nearby Battle of Ancrum Moor in 1545, symbolizing local heritage and the strong female-led production team.

Harry Whitlam died in August 2013 after Gary Green, who was over twice the legal alcohol limit, reversed a vehicle into him at Swithens Farm near Leeds. Green had consumed the equivalent of 13 pints of beer before the incident. Whitlam's family expressed deep sorrow and stressed the dangers of drunk driving, even on private land. Green was jailed for 16 months and two weeks, charged under health and safety laws rather than road traffic laws due to the private location. The Health and Safety Executive investigation revealed Green was reversing a tractor towards a worker in a restricted farm area when the accident occurred, with officials condemning his actions as reckless.

Luis Suarez, the Uruguay striker who recently transferred to Barcelona for £75m, was banned from all football-related activities by FIFA for biting Italy's Giorgio Chiellini during the 2014 World Cup. The Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas) upheld most of the sanctions but ruled that a complete ban from football activities was excessive, allowing Suarez to train, play in friendly matches, attend games, and participate in promotional events. He must still serve an eight-match ban in competitive international games and is likely to make his competitive Barcelona debut at El Clasico on 26 October. Suarez’s appeal argued that FIFA’s punishment was disproportionate, a view partly supported by Cas, though players' union Fifpro criticized the sanctions as too harsh. Suarez had previous suspensions for biting incidents and was also suspended and fined for racial abuse in 2011.

Richard Blake-Smith and his partner Anna won a 380-metre partner-carrying race on 18 March 2014, beating Lithuanian Vytautas Kirkliauskas and his wife. The race involved hurdling haystacks, climbing a steep slope, and dodging water pistols. Participants included various gender and relationship combinations. After their victory, Rich and Anna qualified to compete at the World Championships in Finland in July.

The paper system for car tax discs will be replaced by an electronic system with monthly direct debit payments in October 2014, potentially altering job roles at the DVLA. Minister Stephen Hammond assured that any job reductions would be managed through redeployment rather than redundancies, addressing concerns raised by Swansea East AM Mike Hedges. Hedges welcomed these assurances, acknowledging the benefits of the new system while expressing cautious acceptance of reduced job opportunities.

The passage outlines Hungary's refusal to back down on three controversial laws concerning asylum seekers, NGOs, and higher education, which have drawn EU criticism. Hungary's Minister Szijjarto stated the EU should not interfere in what he calls "domestic issues," and claimed Poland supports vetoing any EU sanctions, including stripping Hungary of its voting rights—a decision requiring unanimous EU approval. The laws include tight asylum seeker controls (such as housing them in secured shipping containers), a higher education law threatening the closure of the prestigious Central European University (founded by George Soros), and forthcoming legislation targeting NGOs by labeling them "foreign-backed." These measures have sparked protests in Hungary and strong concerns from European institutions, with EU officials warning of forthcoming action if Hungary does not amend the laws.

The live-action adaptation of Beauty and the Beast, releasing in US cinemas on March 17, 2017, stars Emma Watson as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, and Luke Evans as Gaston. The film features Mrs Potts, originally voiced by Dame Angela Lansbury, now played by a star actress. Kevin Kline will portray Maurice, Belle's father, and Josh Gad voices Gaston's sidekick LeFou. Directed by Bill Condon, filming starts in May at Shepperton Studios.

Adrian Gill, a distinguished Sunday Times journalist known for his fearless and witty writing, was diagnosed with multiple cancers and underwent chemotherapy. Despite his illness, he remained stoical and continued to write, with his final column addressing his diagnosis. Gill passed away suddenly, prompting tributes from colleagues and notable figures who praised his unique style, intelligence, compassion, and influence on journalism. His career began in the 1980s with art reviews before joining the Sunday Times in 1993. Known for controversial and provocative opinions, Gill often sparked public and media reactions. Born in Edinburgh in 1954, he overcame dyslexia to become a prominent writer. His personal life included two marriages—first to Cressida Connolly, then to Amber Rudd—with whom he had children, and an engagement to partner Nicola Formby, with whom he also had twins.

Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar, a Mongolian rapper known as Amraa and lead singer of Khar Sarnai, was allegedly attacked in Ulan Bator after performing on stage wearing a red deel embroidered with a traditional Mongolian swastika, a symbol predating Nazi use. He was hit with a bottle and kicked in the face, resulting in serious brain injury and about 10 days in a coma. The accused attacker is a Russian diplomatic officer whose identity has not been revealed. The Russian embassy is investigating but called local reports distorted. Sukhbaatar’s family and associates denied claims he shouted Nazi slogans. Mongolian police confirmed the investigation is ongoing and stated that the suspect was not detained due to the injury's severity, not diplomatic immunity. The swastika in Mongolia is a cultural symbol, though it is also used by some far-right groups.

Campaigners from Plane Stupid protested against the airport's expansion by staging a demonstration on the northern runway at 03:30 BST on Monday. They were charged with aggravated trespass and entering a security restricted area and will appear in court on 19 August. The Metropolitan Police stated that airport security would be reviewed.

The passage describes a cricket match between Glamorgan and Gloucestershire, highlighting key performances and conditions. Glamorgan's innings was led by Nick Selman, who scored a mature 101 runs off 144 balls, marking his second first-class century and a return to form after several low scores. Aneurin Donald contributed a quick 36 runs. Bowlers Matt Taylor and Craig Miles were effective for Gloucestershire, regularly taking wickets in cloudy conditions. Glamorgan captain Michael Hogan led in the absence of Jacques Rudolph. Gloucestershire struggled batting under pressure, with their innings described as a survival effort, ending the day evenly balanced. Both Selman and Taylor offered post-match reflections on their innings and playing conditions, noting the challenges and successes faced.

Craig Hughes, 33, from Flint, was arrested after making online threats to ambush and shoot police officers on the Dee Estuary by falsely reporting a crime. He admitted two charges at Mold Crown Court and will be sentenced next week. The threats were made while he was intoxicated. Hughes has a previous firearm conviction from 2009 and was on bail for firearms charges at the time, though he was later cleared. His legal team stated he did not intend to carry out the threats or harm himself. The Hope Line Crisis Centre in Tennessee, which provides confidential support, was involved in reporting the threats.

Surrey posted a strong total of 255-7, highlighted by a 130-run partnership between Davies and Ben Foakes (90). Yorkshire's chase was hindered by Stuart Meaker's quick three-wicket burst, dismissing key batsmen including Jonny Bairstow and Gary Ballance. Despite Tim Bresnan’s 68 and efforts from Matthew Waite, Yorkshire were all out for 236. Surrey captain Gareth Batty praised the team's collective performance, especially the Davies-Foakes partnership, while Yorkshire captain Alex Lees expressed disappointment, noting the team's inability to perform under pressure despite strong bowling.

A 56ft converted trawler located 6 miles west of South Stack experienced flooding, prompting the crew to radio coastguards at 07:00 BST. The onboard pump couldn't manage the incoming water, so the RNLI lifeboat crew provided a pump and towed the vessel to Holyhead.

Laura Muir, a 24-year-old middle-distance runner pursuing a veterinary medicine degree, will miss next year's Commonwealth Games on Australia's Gold Coast due to exam commitments in May. She recently achieved fourth and sixth places in the 1500m and 5000m at the World Athletics Championships, setting a new outdoor personal best of 14:52.07 in the 5000m. Despite being disappointed to miss the Commonwealths, she prioritizes completing her final university year, with hopes to compete in the World Indoor Championships in March. Muir is optimistic about her future, anticipating participation in at least two or three more Olympics.

Robbie Savage's BBC Sport column analyzes Liverpool's struggles six months after Steven Gerrard's slip cost them the Premier League title. Liverpool are currently far from challenging for the title and must aim just to finish in the top four, which should be seen as success under Brendan Rodgers. The departure of Luis Suarez and injury to Daniel Sturridge have devastated their goal-scoring, with Rodgers' replacements lacking quality and work-rate, causing a drop in early goals and overall intensity. Defensively, despite heavy spending and new signings like Lovren and Sakho, Liverpool remain vulnerable and lack leadership, with goalkeeper Simon Mignolet failing to command the area effectively. Rodgers is expected to field a strong lineup against Chelsea but a Liverpool win seems unlikely given Chelsea's superior current form. The match will be tough for Gerrard, who faces physical and mental challenges maintaining his performance and long-term role at Liverpool despite past setbacks. Savage praises Gerrard's continuing importance and resilience, emphasizing that his desire and experience remain vital to the team.

A £45 million educational facility is planned for Sutherland Drive in Kilmarnock, encompassing primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school, and a childcare centre. East Ayrshire Council intends to seek the McIlvanney family's permission to name the campus after William McIlvanney, a celebrated Kilmarnock-born writer known as the "Godfather of Tartan Noir." McIlvanney, who transitioned from teaching English to a full-time writing career in 1975, authored the acclaimed Laidlaw trilogy and other notable works. He was also a poet, journalist, broadcaster, and contributor to Scottish political and sporting discourse. He passed away at his Glasgow home on 5 December.

A suspected British sea mine from the 1940s or 1950s was found near the swimming pool area in Gourock, prompting evacuation of three nearby streets and safety advice for residents within 500m. An exclusion zone of about half a mile was established at sea, disrupting local ferry services. Authorities conducted a precautionary evacuation and advised residents to stay indoors. Due to the mine's deterioration and uncertain explosive content, it was moved to a safer location before disposal. Officials thanked residents for their patience during the operation.

The passage details UK Sport’s funding decisions for Team GB’s preparation for the Tokyo 2020 Olympic and Paralympic Games. A total of £345 million has been allocated to 31 sports, slightly less than the £347 million for Rio 2016. Targets set are 51-85 Olympic medals and 115-162 Paralympic medals, down from Rio’s 67 Olympic and 147 Paralympic medals. Notably, archery, fencing, weightlifting, and wheelchair rugby lost funding entirely, and cycling saw a £4m+ cut despite winning 12 medals in Rio. Badminton, despite winning a bronze medal in Rio and previous strong performances, lost all funding, sparking criticism from its officials. Judo’s funding increased slightly. UK Sport and government representatives emphasized the need to prioritize investment to protect medal potential. Some team sports like basketball, handball, and volleyball have repeatedly lost funding and criticize UK Sport’s reluctance to support team sports. New sports added for Tokyo include baseball/softball, karate, skateboard, sports climbing, surfing, Para-taekwondo, and Para-badminton, with £9m of the budget still unallocated pending medal potential assessments. British Baseball expresses optimism about securing future investment.

Three Victorian hotels in Bournemouth's East Cliff—Bay View Court, The Cottonwood, and Ocean View—will be demolished to build a six-storey, 90-room four-star hotel and two assisted-living apartment blocks (nine and seven storeys, totaling 122 units). Despite strong objections from English Heritage and local residents concerned about harm to the conservation area's historic character, the council voted 7-3 in favor, citing tourism benefits and improving living for older people. The development by East Cliff Project LLP has significant local support, with 246 letters backing the plans.

Pte Matthew Boyd, 20, a soldier with the Royal Gibraltar Regiment, was fatally attacked off-duty outside a bar in Brecon after a night of drinking. Jake Vallely, 24, who had been boasting about being the "hardest man in Brecon," punched and beat Boyd until he was unconscious, then fled the scene. Vallely will be sentenced on 8 December. His friend Aaeron Evans was cleared of involvement, as he was not present during the attack. The assault shocked the local community, with police urging people to avoid violence. Boyd’s family described him as a lively, caring individual with a promising future, expressing their profound loss and the void left by Vallely’s actions, while acknowledging community support as a source of strength.

Andrew Travers left his role as Barnet Council chief executive by "mutual agreement" following a polling error where voters at all 155 borough polling stations were initially turned away due to missing names on the poll list. An independent investigation has been launched to review the incident and the council's arrangements for the upcoming EU Referendum. Deputy chief executive John Hooton will serve as temporary chief executive. The council apologized, offered emergency proxy votes to affected residents, and plans to publicly share investigation findings by the end of May. Travers attributed the problem to issues with electoral registration lists.

Josh Gillies scored a free-kick to give Gateshead the lead, but Wrexham equalized before half-time through Sean Newton's set-piece. Ryan Bowman then secured the win for Gateshead with a header from a cross by Craig Baxter. Gateshead manager Malcolm Crosby praised the team's second-half performance and goal quality, while Wrexham manager Gary Mills expressed disappointment with his team's second-half play and missed chances. The match ended 2-1 in favor of Gateshead.
The Global AgeWatch Index 2014 assesses the social and economic welfare of people over 60 in 96 countries, ranking Norway highest and Afghanistan lowest, with Mozambique also near the bottom.

The passage describes OneWeb's plan to create a global broadband network starting with at least 600 satellites, eventually exceeding 2,000, aiming to connect every corner of the globe, particularly schools. This requires a major shift in satellite manufacturing, moving from costly, bespoke builds to high-volume, low-cost assembly line production, akin to automotive factories, with Airbus leading this effort. Airbus and OneWeb have established an initial assembly line in Toulouse, France, with two more planned in Florida, featuring innovations like a trolley robot for satellite movement. The launch campaign involves over 20 Soyuz rockets, aiming for around 300 satellites in orbit by early 2021, 600 by late 2021, and over 800 by mid-decade. OneWeb holds a first-mover advantage amidst competition from SpaceX, Boeing, and others, backed by $1.7 billion equity and ongoing financing efforts. Registered in the UK Channel Islands, OneWeb works with the UK Space Agency and contributes economically to the UK, fostering a local ecosystem. Debris mitigation is a significant concern, prompting commitments from OneWeb to de-orbit satellites within two years and incorporate hardware to ensure reliability and capture of failed satellites to prevent space junk. While the new manufacturing approach may disrupt the industry, Airbus notes that some specialized missions will still require traditional "gold-plated" satellite production.

The passage discusses the financial pressures facing Scotland due to UK government austerity measures. Mr. John Swinney, the Scottish finance minister, highlights that UK-imposed budget cuts since 2010 and the recent spending review will reduce Scotland’s discretionary budget by 12.5% in real terms by 2019-20, with over £1 billion in cuts still forthcoming. Despite these cuts, Swinney commits to protecting key public services like schools, hospitals, and police from austerity. The UK government counters that Scotland will have £390 million more in spending next year (rising to £750 million including underspends), arguing this is favorable compared to the Scottish government's preferred constitutional alternatives. Labour's Jackie Baillie criticizes Swinney for a lack of clear long-term budgeting and promises Labour will provide a genuine alternative to austerity with different tax decisions.

The passage highlights the challenges faced by people with severe disabilities and their carers due to the lack of suitable accessible toilets, particularly Changing Places toilets, which provide extra space and equipment like hoists and benches for safe and dignified changing. While standard accessible toilets may suffice for some, many require these enhanced facilities. Campaigners, including families like Lorna Fillingham’s, are pushing to make Changing Places toilets compulsory in larger new buildings (shopping centres, cinemas, stadiums) through building regulations, as current guidelines are only recommendations. The psychological and practical impact on families without access to these toilets is emphasized, with examples of community support and positive outcomes at venues like Arsenal Football Club and Cardiff’s Principality Stadium. Barriers to wider installation include space and cost, especially in existing buildings. The passage underscores the need for clearer legal requirements to ensure equal access and inclusion for disabled people.

A group of Italian consumers' organizations filed a formal complaint with the European Commission accusing McDonald's of forcing franchisees to pay excessive rents and high fees. Supported by unions including SEIU and the UK Bakers Food and Allied Workers Union, the complaint alleges McDonald's abuses its market dominance by imposing long contracts and above-market lease rates, limiting franchisees' ability to switch competitors. McDonald's defends its model as a risk-and-reward partnership benefiting franchisees and customers. The European Commission will review the complaint and may investigate if justified. Franchisees operate 73% of McDonald's European restaurants, with franchised outlets generating $9.27 billion in revenues globally in 2014.

A #prayforjosh poster appeared in Holywood as part of a viral social media campaign supporting 13-year-old Joshua Martin from Donaghadee, County Down, who was diagnosed with cancer on Christmas Eve. Initially scheduled for an appendix operation, doctors found and removed a large primary cancer and smaller growths. The campaign began as a hashtag by Bangor Elim Church, where Josh's father works, and has gained global support with over 79,000 views and extensive shares. A mystery donor recently funded a large billboard in Holywood, further symbolizing widespread encouragement. Josh’s classmates and the wider community continue to rally behind him as he undergoes recovery.

The UK government is reorganizing military buildings and regiments in Wales, including closing the historic Brecon Barracks, which has operated since 1805 and housed troops who fought at Rorke's Drift. Conservative MP Chris Davies strongly opposes the closure, citing its historical significance, potential impact on local unemployment, and military tourism. Brecon Barracks employs around 175 staff, though jobs are not expected to be at risk. Nearby training facilities at Sennybridge and Dering Lines remain unaffected. Defence Secretary Sir Michael Fallon announced the creation of a specialist light infantry center at St Athan and confirmed closures of Cawdor Barracks in 2024 and Sennybridge storage depot in 2025. Labour's Shadow Defence Secretary Nia Griffith supports restructuring but acknowledges the uncertainty closures bring to affected workers.

The passage discusses the implications of Brexit on the UK fishing industry. Fishing regions in the UK, which strongly supported leaving the EU, face risks of being marginalized in Brexit negotiations. The EU's Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) has been unpopular in the UK, motivating support for Brexit as a chance to regain control over UK waters and boost fish exports. However, fishing contributes only a small fraction to the UK economy, and most commercial fish stocks are in waters shared with EU countries. The UK exports most of its fish to the EU, while much fish consumed domestically is imported from the EU, making market access crucial. Brexit may require trade-offs, potentially allowing EU boats more access to UK waters in exchange for tariff-free market access. The report recommends retaining key CFP elements like science-based quotas and international cooperation post-Brexit, though fisheries management might become fragmented across UK nations. Despite concerns, the industry remains optimistic, citing recent EU quota increases as a positive sign. Government statements emphasize balancing market access with sustainable fisheries management after leaving the EU.

The passage details Edward Snowden, a former CIA technical worker who leaked classified documents revealing extensive US government surveillance practices. The NSA reportedly accessed large-scale data including chat logs, voice traffic, and social networking information through a program called Prism, which allegedly had "backdoor" access to servers of major tech companies like Google, Facebook, and Apple—though these companies denied involvement. The US government also collected millions of Verizon phone records. Officials defended the surveillance as necessary for national security, while critics raised privacy and legal concerns, noting limited transparency. Data stored overseas, particularly in US-based cloud services, is vulnerable under US laws like the Patriot Act. Other governments' involvement remains unclear, with the EU expressing concern and seeking details. Privacy advocates warn that widespread data access threatens user privacy globally, a concern Snowden echoed, justifying his leaks as a defense of individual privacy rights.

The passage describes OpenAI, a venture backed by Elon Musk, Peter Thiel, Infosys, and Amazon Web Services, which aims to conduct AI research free from financial obligations to focus on positive human impact. While some experts like Musk and Stephen Hawking warn AI could threaten humanity by evolving beyond human control, others see the risk as remote. OpenAI's goal is to advance AI beneficially for all, distributing its benefits broadly and safely, with only a small portion of the pledged $1 billion to be spent in the near term.

L/Bdr Ben Parkinson, seriously injured in a 2006 Afghanistan bomb attack, carried the Olympic torch on 26 June with assistance, demonstrating his recovery despite a past brain injury that affected his speech. Since then, he has received thousands of Facebook friend requests but is limited to 5,000 due to site restrictions. Devoted to rehabilitation and fundraising for military charities, Ben is buoyed by vast public support, with his online pages receiving significant traffic and messages. Facebook suggests public figures like him use pages or subscribe options to manage such attention. The Olympic torch relay involves 8,000 carriers over 8,000 miles leading to the London Games opening ceremony on 27 July.

In 2011, the US poverty rate remained steady at 15%, with 46.2 million people in poverty following three years of increases. Real median household income declined by 1.5%, and the average poverty threshold for a family of four was $23,021. Income inequality rose by 1.6%, marking the first annual increase since 1993. The uninsured rate dropped slightly to 15.7% from 16.3%. Poverty had peaked at a record 15.1% in 2010.

Jos Buttler, a 25-year-old short-format cricket specialist who joined Lancashire from Somerset in 2013, has signed a new contract with the club extending until 2019. Known for scoring England's three fastest ODI centuries, including a 46-ball century against Pakistan, Buttler’s performance was key in Lancashire winning last year's T20 Blast final. Praised by coach Ashley Giles for his talent, experience, and positive influence in the team, Buttler, who plays in the Indian Premier League for Mumbai Indians, is set to return for Lancashire’s upcoming T20 Blast home game against Durham.

The decommissioned Type 22 frigates HMS Cumberland, Campbeltown, Chatham, and Cornwall, currently moored in Portsmouth Harbour, are up for sale with bids finalizing after a January 23 registration deadline. No preservation proposals have been received; viewings are scheduled for late February and March, with decisions expected by spring. The government's Disposal Services Authority aims to award at least one frigate to a UK ship recycler to assess domestic recycling capacity. MP Penny Mordaunt supports this but also hopes to preserve at least one ship as a reef and diving attraction to generate tourism income. The Ministry of Defence seeks the best financial return and is considering all options. The Type 22 frigates were advanced anti-submarine and surface combatants with strong command capabilities, crewed by about 280 sailors. Previously, the HMS Ark Royal aircraft carrier was sold for scrap at £3 million.

Since 1987, Fiji has experienced significant racial and political instability marked by multiple coups, including those in 1987, 2000, and 2006, which severely damaged its economy and international standing. The population is roughly divided between indigenous Fijians and Indo-Fijians, with ongoing social segregation and demographic shifts due to emigration. Political tensions, especially around indigenous supremacy and amnesty for coup perpetrators, led to Fiji's 2009 suspension from the Commonwealth, which was lifted after elections in 2014. Despite a diverse economy reliant on sugar, tourism, mining, and services, Fiji faces persistent trade and budget deficits and is a major aid recipient.

The passage details Syria's struggle to meet the deadline for destroying its chemical weapons, with Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad stating Syria is trying its best despite missing the deadline and attacks on shipments en route to the port of Latakia. Mekdad condemned US criticism of Syria's use of barrel bombs in Aleppo, blaming the US for supporting terrorists. Reports conflict over control of Aleppo's central prison, with rebels reportedly seizing it and freeing detainees, though the government denies this. Syria has about 1,300 tonnes of declared chemical weapons, but only 4% has been removed, raising US concerns over delays. Russia urges completion of transfers by 1 March, with a destruction deadline at the end of June. The OPCW acknowledges security issues slowing progress. Mekdad affirms Syria's commitment to fulfilling its obligations under international agreements.

The Lives Of Others by Mukherjee, set in 1960s Calcutta, is the 5/2 favorite to win the 46th Booker Prize, which is open to all English-language authors regardless of nationality. The winner will be announced at London’s Guildhall and the shortlist includes six authors: Howard Jacobson (J), Ali Smith (How To Be Both), Joshua Ferris (To Rise Again at a Decent Hour), Karen Joy Fowler (We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves), Richard Flanagan (The Narrow Road to the Deep North), alongside Mukherjee. Fowler's book is the best-selling on the list with over 55,000 copies sold. The judging panel is chaired by AC Grayling, and each shortlisted author receives £2,500 plus a bound edition of their book. The prize ceremony will be presented by the Duchess of Cornwall and broadcast on BBC.

A man known as PJS is appealing a Court of Appeal ruling that lifted a media ban on naming him in England and Wales. The Supreme Court will decide whether to hear his appeal and if it should be allowed or dismissed, with an interim injunction remaining until the hearing concludes. PJS, who has young children and a public figure spouse, seeks privacy against publication by the Sun on Sunday of alleged extra-marital activities involving him and another person, AB. The Court of Appeal initially granted him anonymity, but later removed the ban, citing widespread public knowledge from international publications and online spread, making confidentiality unenforceable despite efforts to remove breaches. The judges ruled PJS is now unlikely to secure a permanent injunction.

Fosse Park, near junction 21 of the M1, opened in 1989 and was recently purchased for £345.5 million. New owners plan to address parking and traffic congestion issues and improve the appearance of the units. Blaby District Council's leader, Ernie White, noted that the owners view Fosse Park as an important investment and aim to enhance its appearance as the city gateway. Paul Clarke of Crown Estates emphasized their focus on improving parking, congestion, common areas, and facilities to revitalize the somewhat tired shopping park.

The live-action remake of "Beauty and the Beast," which includes a brief "gay moment" involving the character LeFou, faced controversy in Malaysia where homosexual activity is illegal. Although the Malaysian Censorship Board (LPF) approved the film with a minor edit related to this scene and granted it a "P13 parental guidance" rating, Disney postponed its release for content review. The LPF does not control release dates, and local cinemas are offering ticket refunds. The decision sparked public criticism, with many netizens calling the ban "stupid and laughable" and highlighting hypocrisy toward local films. A new release date in Malaysia has yet to be announced.

Landlords renting to more than three unrelated people must obtain a House of Multiple Occupation (HMO) licence, which can cost around £1,000, though failure to comply risks fines up to £20,000, according to Southampton City Council. The council estimates about 1,500 unlicensed HMOs locally. Shelter highlights tenant concerns over eviction and poor property conditions, linked to a shortage of affordable housing. National HMO licensing applies to houses with three or more storeys and five or more unrelated occupants. In Southampton, licensing covers specific areas designated in 2013 and 2015. While most landlords comply, some resist, with the council prosecuting one firm and 13 individuals so far.

Acting Taoiseach Enda Kenny (Fine Gael) and Micheál Martin (Fianna Fáil) aim to avoid a second election after a nearly two-month stalemate following the election where no party secured a majority (Fine Gael 50 seats, Fianna Fáil 44, Sinn Féin 23, Labour 7). Fianna Fáil is willing to facilitate a minority government but will not support its programme, with water charges—a key disagreement—hindering an agreement. Proposals include a commission to review Irish Water’s future; Fianna Fáil wants immediate removal of water charges, while Fine Gael supports maintaining them.

The ferry Sorrento caught fire on a car deck about 27 km from Mallorca while en route to Valencia. The fire quickly escalated, prompting evacuation of passengers onto lifeboats, who were then rescued by nearby ships, including the ferry Puglia. At least three people were injured, one seriously, and taken to hospital by helicopter. The cause of the fire is unknown.
