Laura Muir, a 24-year-old middle-distance runner and veterinary medicine student, will miss next year’s Commonwealth Games on Australia’s Gold Coast due to her final exams in May conflicting with the event in April. Despite this, she remains committed to representing Scotland in future competitions and aims for two to three more Olympics. Recently, Muir placed fourth and sixth in the 1500m and 5000m at the World Athletics Championships, setting a new outdoor personal best of 14:52.07 in the 5000m. She views the upcoming World Indoor Championships in March as a potential target but acknowledges a demanding schedule balancing athletics with her studies.

Trevor Deely, 22, disappeared in December 2000 after leaving a Christmas party. A search began in Chapelizod, Dublin, in a three-acre woodland area near the River Liffey, involving excavations expected to last weeks. Earlier, six detectives reviewed his case, enhancing CCTV footage from the night of his disappearance, which showed Deely talking to an unidentified man dressed in black outside his workplace on Baggot Street. Detectives believe this man followed Deely shortly after and released the footage in April, appealing for his identification. As of the search, the man remains unidentified, and authorities have renewed their appeal for information.

Juan Martin del Potro, ranked 165th after over two years out due to wrist injuries and surgeries, defeated Switzerland's Stan Wawrinka 3-6, 6-3, 7-6(7-2), 6-3 to advance in a Grand Slam, marking his return since the 2014 Australian Open. Del Potro, praised by peers and enjoying a resurgence, will next face either Lucas Pouille or Donald Young. Meanwhile, Australia's Nick Kyrgios overcame Dustin Brown in a rain-interrupted five-set match to reach round three, where he will meet Feliciano Lopez, who came back from two sets down to beat Fabio Fognini. The winner will face either Andy Murray or John Millman in the last 16. Other seeds advancing included Tomas Berdych and Jo-Wilfried Tsonga, both securing straightforward wins.

Tunisia faced potential expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations due to complaints about a controversial penalty awarded against them in the 2015 quarter-final versus Equatorial Guinea, but after apologizing to CAF, they were reinstated. Morocco was banned from the 2017 qualifiers after being stripped of hosting the 2015 tournament for Ebola-related concerns, but the Court of Arbitration for Sport overturned the ban and reduced their fine. Both Tunisia and Morocco have reconciled with CAF and will participate in the 2017 Nations Cup qualifiers. Tunisia aims for a record 13th consecutive Nations Cup appearance, drawn in Group A with Togo, Liberia, and Djibouti; Morocco is in Group F with Cape Verde, Libya, and Sao Tome.

The passage outlines McLaren's significant decline from its former Formula 1 dominance, despite its illustrious history of 182 grand prix wins, 12 drivers' championships, and eight constructors' titles. Once a powerhouse associated with legendary drivers like Ayrton Senna, Alain Prost, and Mika Hakkinen, McLaren faced setbacks starting in 2013 due to chassis design flaws and ongoing issues with Honda engines, marking a sharp contrast to the successful McLaren-Honda partnership of the late 1980s. The team has endured scandals, including a major penalty in 2007 for possessing Ferrari technical secrets and the "lie-gate" incident in 2009. Although recent performance has been dismal, with grid results no better than mid-pack, team principal Ron Dennis remains optimistic about recovery, citing the presence of two world champions, including Fernando Alonso, who rejoined in 2015 seeking a third title. Dennis believes McLaren will eventually break Mercedes' dominance and return to winning multiple championships, but currently, the team’s hopes rest primarily on faith amid ongoing challenges.

Paramedics responded to a sudden death at Joe's Bar in Dungiven on 6 October 2014, where police found patrons still present despite alcohol sales recorded as late as 04:49 BST. At Limavady Magistrates Court, Colleen O'Neill, the license holder, was charged with two counts and James Thomas with one count of allowing liquor consumption outside licensing hours. The court was told the bar routinely ignored licensing laws, operating into the early morning. The judge condemned O'Neill's poor record, imposed a three-month closure of the bar, fined her £3,000, fined Thomas £1,000, and expressed frustration over the inability to impose custodial sentences.

Stephen Curry broke his own NBA record for most three-pointers in a season by making eight threes, surpassing his previous mark of 272, and scored 45 points to lead the Golden State Warriors to a 116-105 comeback win over the Portland Trail Blazers. Klay Thompson contributed 26 points and nine assists for the Warriors, helping them avoid their first three-game losing streak. For the Blazers, LaMarcus Aldridge scored 27 points and Damian Lillard added 20 points and eight assists. In another game, the Chicago Bulls overcame a 19-point halftime deficit to defeat the Miami Heat 89-78, with Pau Gasol posting 16 points and 15 rebounds, Derrick Rose scoring 12 points in his comeback, and Miami struggling after halftime, shooting poorly and being outscored 57-27.

YouTube star and free-kick specialist Bas van Velzen surprised Liverpool players Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert, and Lazar Markovic at Melwood. Initially presented as a competition winner receiving a dead-ball masterclass, van Velzen instead showcased impressive free-kick skills that amazed the players. Van Velzen, known for his YouTube free-kick videos, enjoyed the experience of playing with his idols and even surprised Balotelli by unveiling his famous slogan, referencing Balotelli’s iconic 2011 t-shirt worn during a Manchester City match.

The passage discusses a study showing that women with breast cancer caused by the BRCA1 gene mutation, like Angelina Jolie, can significantly reduce their risk of death by having their ovaries removed through oophorectomy. Analysis of 676 breast cancer patients with BRCA mutations found that oophorectomy lowered breast cancer death by 62% in BRCA1 carriers, with a 73% reduction when performed within two years of diagnosis, and a 65% reduction in overall mortality. The protective effect lasts up to 15 years and is especially notable in estrogen-receptor negative breast cancer. The procedure did not show similar benefits for BRCA2 carriers. The article emphasizes the importance of considering oophorectomy as part of treatment discussions for BRCA1 mutation carriers and calls for further research, particularly for BRCA2 carriers. Women with BRCA mutations face a 50-80% lifetime breast cancer risk, and genetic testing is advised for those with a significant family history. Angelina Jolie, who underwent oophorectomy after a double mastectomy, reported feeling empowered and feminine following her surgeries.

A married couple, Derek Lowe (38) and Tina Lowe (33), were struck and killed by Amtrak train No. 80, the Carolinian, on Easter morning in Durham, North Carolina, while lingering on the tracks. The train was traveling north from Charlotte to New York City on Norfolk-Southern property. None of the 166 passengers were injured, though a man fell ill during the nearly three-hour delay caused by the accident. The couple, possibly homeless, were last seen with a grocery cart and known to a scrap metal collector who described their difficult crossing of the tracks. After the delay, the train resumed its approximately 13.5-hour journey toward New York City.

Carlos Toro, a former Medellin cartel member who worked undercover for the DEA for 27 years in exchange for a promised U.S. citizenship, now faces deportation after retiring due to health issues. Despite his significant contributions, including aiding in the takedown of drug kingpins like Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega, Toro has not received citizenship and is living illegally in the U.S. The DEA has refused to assist him, leaving him unable to access social security benefits and with his visa expired. Fearing for his life if deported to Colombia, Toro seeks fulfillment of the promise made to him after years of service.

The U.S. regulator ICANN is investigating Canadian company Vox Populi Registry Ltd. for potentially illegal practices involving the new ".sucks" domain name. The company has been charging celebrities and major brands, including Kevin Spacey, YouTube, Bing, Visa, Bank of America, and Yahoo, exorbitant fees (around $2,499 per year) to register or remove these domains. While Vox Populi claims the domains offer a platform for companies to engage with critics and insists its business is lawful, industry groups have called the scheme predatory and a "shakedown." ICANN has requested U.S. and Canadian regulatory scrutiny and may take action against Vox Populi if found in breach of contract. The ".sucks" domains became available on March 30, with an initial phase for trademark holders before public release at a lower cost.

A baby boy's body was discovered in 1988 floating in a pond in Weasenham St Peter, Norfolk, wrapped in a blanket inside a Sainsbury’s bag. The infant was buried anonymously after villagers raised funds for the burial. In 2022, police exhumed the body for a case review and used DNA from the remains to identify the mother, who had concealed her pregnancy and delivered the baby stillborn. She was arrested on suspicion of infanticide, but the charge was dropped after she explained the baby’s death and secret birth. Subsequent investigations ruled out foul play or third-party involvement. The baby, named Peter after the local church, was reburied with a new headstone funded by a support charity for stillbirth families. Norfolk police expressed satisfaction in solving the 27-year-old mystery using modern DNA techniques while showing empathy for the woman involved.

A taxi driver, Michael Young, was ordered by the High Court to pay compensation for unlawfully imprisoning passenger Kristopher Hicks, who suffered severe brain injuries after jumping from the moving taxi. The incident occurred five years ago in Bath, Somerset, when Young, suspecting Hicks intended to flee without paying, drove him nearly a mile back to the taxi rank against his will. Hicks jumped from the vehicle traveling over 20 mph, resulting in devastating brain injuries, epilepsy, and lifelong need for round-the-clock care. The judge ruled Young's actions significantly endangered Hicks, awarding damages reduced by 50%, plus £250 for unlawful imprisonment, with the exact compensation amount pending. Hicks, now 27, remains under care for ongoing disabilities stemming from the 2010 incident.

Several tornadoes and severe storms struck Kansas Wednesday night, with a tornado reported near Goddard northwest of Wichita and others near Aetna in southwestern Kansas. Nighttime tornadoes, noted as especially dangerous, continued to pose risks. Missouri also experienced a possible tornado in Potosi, causing wind damage and flooding, with reports of hail near Farmington. More storms were forecasted for the Midwest and surrounding regions on Thursday.

Luke Rockhold and Lyoto Machida are set to face off in a middleweight fight in New Jersey, with both seeking a title shot. Rockhold, aiming for his fourth straight win since a loss two years ago, plans to play the aggressive "bull" against Machida's elusive "matador" style by cutting him off, using a diverse skill set, and exploiting Machida's weaknesses both on the feet and on the ground. He respects Machida’s longstanding fighting style and career but is determined to dominate. Machida, coming off a recent win in Brazil, is confident in his technique and strategy to upset Rockhold and earn a title shot, acknowledging the importance of adapting during the fight. Both fighters have prepared extensively, with Rockhold training to improve endurance and Machida completing an eight-week camp with top fighters.

A light general aviation Aerostar plane in Fort Pierce, Florida, landed on a runway without its landing gear deployed, causing it to skid on its belly and damage its propellers as it touched down. The pilot then re-engaged the engines and took off again despite the damage. Remarkably, the pilot, Chris Georgaklis, aged 85 and an experienced flyer of nearly 50 years, managed to fly 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale and land safely. The incident, captured on video, highlighted the pilot’s initial mistake and unexpected successful recovery. The FAA is investigating, noting that gear-up landings often result from human error or mechanical failure.

Manuel Pellegrini expressed disappointment in Manchester City midfielder Yaya Toure's underperformance this season but pledged to support him at least until the season's end. Despite criticism amid City's faltering Premier League campaign and reports they would consider offers for Toure in the summer, Pellegrini emphasized Toure's importance and dismissed the idea of giving him a rest. The team faces challenges including injuries to captain Vincent Kompany and pressure on Pellegrini's own future. Goalkeeper Joe Hart acknowledged the players' responsibility for poor results but affirmed Pellegrini's backing within the squad. Meanwhile, West Ham's Sam Allardyce, whose team faces City next, cautioned his player Aaron Cresswell about the risks of moving to City, referencing past cases where English players struggled for game time there, despite City's interest in signing Cresswell to bolster their homegrown player quota.

Domenico Rancadore, a Sicilian mafia fugitive known as the "Godfather of Uxbridge," will be allowed to remain in the UK after his seven-year prison sentence for mafia association, handed down in 1999 by an Italian court, was dropped. Having lived in Britain for over 20 years under an assumed name, Rancadore was arrested in 2013 on a European arrest warrant and faced extradition. However, his sentence expired in October 2014 under Italian law, which extinguishes convictions if more than twice the penalty period passes. The Italian court of appeal agreed to extinguish the conviction in March 2015, leading to the withdrawal of the European arrest warrant. The UK Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) will seek a consent order to discharge Rancadore, with a judge’s approval pending. The case was prolonged by CPS administrative errors, and the Italian authorities’ delayed communications contributed to the unresolved extradition. Despite the conviction remaining, Rancadore will live peacefully in England with his family. The passage also provides context on the Sicilian mafia’s origins, organization, and economic impact.

Mr Mole, ridden by AP McCoy and trained by Paul Nicholls, is one of three 7-2 co-favourites for the Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown on Saturday. He is competing against six rivals, including Irish raider Special Tiara and Nicky Henderson’s Sprinter Sacre, who will be ridden by Nico de Boinville. The race will be McCoy’s last Grade One ride before retirement, with his final rides to be confirmed on Friday. Notably, McCoy announced his retirement after winning on Mr Mole at Newbury in February. Another competitor in the race is Mick Channon’s Somersby.

Virginia Trimble Ritter, whose daughter Marcia was raped and murdered in 1975 by Jerome Sidney Barrett, recently viewed crime scene photos of her daughter's body for the first time in 40 years, a decision she now regrets but pursued seeking closure and revenge. Marcia's body was found 33 days after her disappearance in a nearby garage, showing signs of strangulation, sexual assault, and bodily injuries. Barrett, who was imprisoned on other sex charges for much of the intervening years, was arrested in 2006 after DNA linked him to Marcia’s murder and was convicted in 2009, receiving a 44-year sentence. The case remained Nashville’s most notorious unsolved murder for over three decades until Barrett's conviction.

Rory McIlroy, world number one golfer, is determined to win the Masters to complete the career grand slam, joining a select group of players including Nicklaus and Woods. Despite only one top-10 Masters finish in six attempts, he views winning at Augusta as a lifelong goal and believes it’s unthinkable to go through his career without securing a green jacket. His final-round collapse in the 2011 Masters, where he squandered a four-shot lead, was pivotal in his development, teaching him valuable lessons that helped him win subsequent majors. Last year, despite personal distractions such as calling off his wedding and legal issues, McIlroy achieved significant success and sees the golf course as a sanctuary amid pressure. He looks forward to Augusta as both a challenge and opportunity to add the elusive Masters title to his achievements.

The passage summarizes notable trending stories of the week, including four rainbows over New York after heavy rain captured by Amanda Curtis; China's crackdown on exotic dancers hired for wakes; Robert Downey Jr. becoming agitated during a UK interview; the viral lip plumping trend mimicking Kylie Jenner; 102-year-old Alice Barker revisiting the past with filmmakers; a controversial bomb-referencing prom-posal accused of racism; Ewan McGregor cast as Lumiere in "Beauty and the Beast"; Johnny Depp's nearly unrecognizable role in the "Black Mass" trailer; a pregnancy announcement referencing "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air"; and a military dad photobombing his son. All these stories generated significant social media attention.

Last year, 272 children with foetal alcohol syndrome (FAS) were hospitalized in England due to brain damage from prenatal alcohol exposure, though experts believe many more are affected. Research by the World Health Organization estimates that about 1 in 100 UK babies, roughly 7,500 annually, suffer from learning, behavioral, and physical problems caused by alcohol exposure in the womb. FAS is a lifelong and under-diagnosed condition causing disabilities such as limb deformities and cognitive impairments. Affected individuals, like 15-year-old Niamh Brown, often require lifelong care. Additional health issues linked to prenatal alcohol include liver, kidney, and heart problems, cerebral palsy, vision loss, and epilepsy. Though current UK guidelines allow limited alcohol consumption during pregnancy, advocates urge a complete abstinence recommendation.

Shaun Andrew Mckerry, a 31-year-old ex-juvenile offender from Coundon, was jailed for six years after attempting to rob the Shildon post office and stores in County Durham on March 15. Armed with an axe and masked, Mckerry demanded cash from assistant Andrea Brighty but was tackled to the floor by owner Sab Dhillon. Dhillon’s wife, Sam, assisted by hitting Mckerry twice with a baseball bat, disarming him. Mckerry, known as "boomerang boy" due to his frequent criminal returns, had a long history of offenses since age 12, including shoplifting, burglary, and other crimes. Police arrived minutes after the incident and arrested him following his guilty plea for attempted robbery.

Four Royal Navy sailors—Joshua Finbow, Simon Radford, Craig Stoner, and Darren Smalley—are charged with gang raping a young woman at an alcohol-fueled party at the Shearwater naval base near Halifax, Nova Scotia, after a hockey game on April 10. They appeared in Dartmouth court and were granted bail under strict conditions requiring them to remain in Nova Scotia, live at Stadacona naval base, surrender their passports, and continue working for the Royal Navy on pay. They are prohibited from contacting the victim or six witnesses and must not leave the province or resign without court permission. The accused face charges that carry up to 14 years in prison, with investigations ongoing and the possibility of additional charges. The British High Commission is assisting Canadian authorities, and the case remains in early stages.

The passage tells the story of Valerie Jackson, mother to four-year-old RJ Jackson from Las Vegas, who has a rare genetic skin disease called Netherton's syndrome affecting only about 70 people worldwide. The syndrome causes RJ's skin to appear red, inflamed, scaly, and painful, often mistaken for scalding or abuse. Because of this, Mrs. Jackson has faced public ignorance, cruel taunts, and even police intervention after a stranger accused her of child abuse while she was applying creams to soothe RJ’s skin. RJ’s condition causes ongoing symptoms requiring frequent moisturizing and careful care, with no cure available. Despite social challenges and exclusion from play areas, Mrs. Jackson expresses love for her son and hopes awareness of Netherton's syndrome will improve as he grows.

The passage discusses the controversy surrounding Protein World's "Are you beach body ready?" advertising campaign in London Underground, featuring a bikini-clad model, Renee Somerfield. The posters sparked backlash from feminists and body image campaigners, gaining over 50,000 petition signatures and over 200 complaints to the Advertising Standards Authority (ASA) for promoting unhealthy body image. Some posters were defaced, and a protest was planned in Hyde Park. Transport for London confirmed poster removal after the paid advertising period ended, noting customer feedback would influence future campaigns. Protein World defended the ads on social media, engaging critics with blunt responses. TV presenter Susanna Reid called the ads "anxiety inducing" on Good Morning Britain, interviewing Protein World's marketing head, Richard Staveley, who defended the campaign's focus on fitness and health. The company reported receiving threats, including a bomb threat under police investigation. The ASA was reviewing complaints for possible action. Sales of protein powder are rising in the UK. Some public figures, like Katie Hopkins and Samantha Brick, supported the ads, encouraging fitness and confidence.

Rail companies plan significant fare hikes, with increases up to 87% starting May 17, shortly after the general election, despite promises from main political parties to freeze prices. Prime Minister David Cameron has urged First Great Western (FGW) to urgently review its decision to nearly double fares on the London to Cotswolds route through his constituency. For example, off-peak returns from Charlbury to London will rise from £33.30 to £62.40. FGW justifies the hike by aligning prices with other routes and offers cheaper advanced single tickets as alternatives. Other companies, including Virgin and London Midlands, also plan increases ranging from 22% to 40% on various routes. Virgin states most increases apply to their discounted "virgin trains-only" fares, with an overall increase of 1.65% on the West Coast line, below industry average. Public and political backlash has arisen due to the fare hikes contradicting political pledges to cap or freeze rail prices.

Former soldier John Young, 66, and his wife Elaine, 54, were attacked at their Oldham home when vandals threw stones and bricks at their front window and door. When John confronted the attackers after a brick smashed the door glass, he was hit directly in the left eye by another brick, resulting in serious injury and permanent blindness in that eye despite emergency surgery. The attack occurred late at night on April 18, just three weeks after their wedding. Police have launched an investigation but found no clear motive, suggesting the vandals may have been “messing around.” The couple, feeling unsafe, plan to move away, while authorities urge witnesses to come forward to identify those responsible.

Derbyshire wicketkeeper Tom Poynton, 25, has signed a one-year contract extension after successfully returning from leg injuries sustained in a road accident that also resulted in his father's death. Missing the entire 2014 season, Poynton underwent ankle surgery and made his comeback during Derbyshire's pre-season tour of Abu Dhabi. The club praised his exceptional character and hard work, expressing confidence that the new contract will help him perform well in the upcoming season through to the end of 2016.

A five-year-old boy named Harley Renshaw was diagnosed with neuroblastoma, a rare and aggressive childhood cancer affecting fewer than 100 children annually in the UK. His cancer spread across his kidney, neck, lungs, and bones. To help cope with treatment, including 80 days of intensive chemotherapy, surgery to remove a kidney tumor, a stem cell transplant, and weeks of radiotherapy, Harley decorated his protective radiotherapy mask as a Ninja Turtle, which boosted his bravery. His story gained widespread attention, earning him gifts from Nickelodeon and a Cancer Research UK "little star" award. After a year-long battle, doctors declared Harley cancer-free. He will continue regular check-ups and has become the face of a charity campaign raising funds for childhood cancer research. Neuroblastoma affects specialized nerve cells in the nervous system, with symptoms varying by tumor location, and treatment options include surgery, chemotherapy, antibody therapy, and radiotherapy.

Tim Sherwood advises Jack Grealish to prioritize his Aston Villa career over his international allegiance, as Grealish is currently deciding between playing for the Republic of Ireland or England. Sherwood praises the 19-year-old's confident performances, notably in Villa’s FA Cup semi-final win over Liverpool, emphasizing the importance of gaining more first-team experience before choosing internationally. Grealish’s father, Kevin, agrees that club focus should come first. Grealish, who has represented Ireland at youth level, is torn between the two countries and is expected to make his decision by the season’s end.

The passage discusses the significant variation in private jet landing fees at airports worldwide, highlighting some unexpectedly expensive locations. Private jet travel is a luxury predominantly for the wealthy, with growing popularity evidenced by millions of private flights annually in the US and Europe. Major sporting events like the Super Bowl and Monaco Grand Prix drive peak private jet traffic and high travel costs. The highest landing fees are notably found in Japan, with Haneda Airport charging £4,559 ($6,850), followed by Narita and Kansai airports. Other costly airports include Toronto, Darwin (Australia), Bristol (UK), Dublin (Ireland), LaGuardia (US), and Salzburg (Austria). Fees reflect both airport prestige and passenger volume, emphasizing the exclusivity and expense of private jet travel.

Katie Gallegos from Clackamas County, Oregon, shared videos of her dog Cooper, a fast-eating Labrador, enjoying ice cream from a McDonald’s drive-thru with his smaller canine friend, Daisy. While Daisy licks the ice cream slowly, Cooper quickly devours it in one bite. The videos, viewed over seven million times, have received mixed reactions—some find them cute, while others criticize feeding dogs treats like ice cream. Gallegos, who operates a dog resort, defends the practice by citing Cooper’s excellent health and past experience with similar treats. The dogs also enjoy occasional “pup-uccinos” from Starbucks, which are just whipped cream without coffee.

Gary Locke, previously assistant manager at Kilmarnock and former Hearts boss, has been appointed permanent manager on a three-year contract. He took over as interim manager in February after Allan Johnston's departure and has lost only once in seven games since. Locke will address the media at a press conference on Friday.

A Florida mother, Jessica Kemp, accused Seminole County Elementary of threatening to suspend her five-year-old autistic son, Logan, over essential oils he wears to help manage his condition. Jessica applies doTERRA oils like lavender, chamomile, and sandalwood to his head and neck, believing they keep him calm and focused. Although Logan has used the oils all year, a teacher's aide complained about their smell being a distraction. The school board sent a letter citing the oils as a problem for staff and students. Despite this, the Lake County School District later stated they would not suspend Logan, recognizing it as a health issue. Jessica intends to continue advocating for her son's use of the oils.

A fire destroyed the Sandpiper beach-side apartment complex in Westhampton Beach on Wednesday afternoon, engulfing 90 condos before the building collapsed. The blaze was so intense that it melted paint off nearby buildings, and smoke was visible from three miles away. Twelve fire crews attempted to control the fire but could not enter the building, using cranes instead. The cause of the fire is under investigation, with suspicions it started near a parked car. Residents, including owners Janice Sklarek and building manager Rob Taber, who lost everything, expressed shock and distress. The complex serves as a holiday home open from May to November.

The passage describes the Queen's enduring love for horses, particularly fell ponies. Approaching her 89th birthday, she was seen riding her black fell pony, Carltonlima Emma, in Windsor Great Park, choosing to forgo a helmet in favor of a silk scarf due to her distinctive hair. She began riding at age four with a Shetland pony named Peggy and has owned various notable horses, including Betsy and Surprise. Although a knee injury has reduced her riding frequency and caused her to stop riding in events like Trooping the Colour, she remains an enthusiastic equestrienne and actively breeds horses and ponies, including fell ponies and highland ponies at Hampton Court and Balmoral. Fell ponies, one of the oldest equine breeds, have a long history extending from Neolithic times through Roman and Viking use, serving as pack animals and trade ponies, and remain popular today for their docile nature. The Queen continues to keep and breed these ponies, underscoring her lifelong dedication to equestrian pursuits.

A dispute over noise between Brisbane neighbors led to the death of 55-year-old Leon Yeaman, allegedly killed by a single punch from 28-year-old Phillip Pama during an argument outside their homes. Yeaman was making loud noise in his yard late Thursday night, disturbing Pama, who worked early shifts and was sleeping. Pama confronted Yeaman and struck him blindly during the confrontation. Yeaman died at the scene, and Pama was charged with manslaughter. Pama was granted conditional bail with restrictions and has no prior violent history. The case will return to court on May 18.

Yulia Simonova, a 52-year-old Russian music teacher, was caught on a hidden camera hiring a hitman to torture and murder her 15-year-old student, Damian Vanya, after he ended their relationship. She offered 100,000 rubles (£1,400) for the attack, detailing her desire for him to suffer severe injuries and bleed to death before she would "finish" him. Police conducted a sting operation using an undercover officer posing as the hitman, during which Simonova handed over some expenses money before being arrested. She now faces 15 years in prison on attempted murder charges. Damian Vanya, who ended the affair after starting a relationship with a classmate, expressed relief at her arrest, hoping she is securely imprisoned.

Chelsea football manager José Mourinho, a 52-year-old father of two, reveals his strong faith in God, praying daily but never about football or his professional life, which he keeps separate from family. He rarely attends church except when in Portugal and prays only for personal matters. Mourinho emphasizes his role as a good family man and friend, acknowledging the competitiveness and emotional intensity of his career. His family is involved in charitable work with the World Food Programme against hunger. Despite his on-field arrogance, he maintains a positive personal reputation. Chelsea, currently top of the league, face struggling QPR soon. Mourinho was fined £25,000 earlier for alleging a campaign against Chelsea.

Bob Barker, the longtime host of "The Price Is Right" who retired in 2007 after 35 years, made a special return to the show on April 1 for the first time in eight years. At 91, he appeared lively as he hosted the classic "Lucky Seven" game before handing the hosting duties back to current host Drew Carey. Barker performed smoothly despite his long absence.

An off-duty Secret Service agent, Arthur Baldwin, was arrested in Washington D.C. at 12:30 am on Friday for allegedly attempting to break into a house on the 3200 block of D Street SE. He faces felony charges of attempted burglary and destruction of property. Following the arrest, the agency revoked his security clearance and placed him on leave. Baldwin is assigned to the Foreign Missions branch, which supports U.S. diplomatic activities. He was scheduled for arraignment Friday afternoon. Baldwin's arrest comes shortly after a high-ranking supervisor was also placed on leave due to separate misconduct allegations under investigation by the Homeland Security inspector general. These incidents add to ongoing scrutiny of the Secret Service, which is also investigating previous misconduct involving officials driving into a White House secure area after drinking.

Freelance photographer Atif Saeed, 38, from Lahore, Pakistan, risked his life to photograph a hungry male lion at the city's safari park. Leaving his car, he crept within 10 feet of the lion armed only with a camera and managed to capture a few shots. The camera shutter alerted the lion, which then aggressively approached him, forcing Saeed to quickly retreat to safety. Reflecting on the incident, he acknowledged it was a close and dangerous encounter he likely would not repeat.

New York City police released images of a distinctive heart-shaped tattoo with the name "Monique" found on the right leg of an unidentified woman who died nearly a month ago in Brooklyn. The woman, estimated to be 25 to 45 years old, was found unconscious on March 22 near Shore Parkway and 26th Avenue in Gravesend and was pronounced dead that evening. She had no identification, and authorities are awaiting a medical examiner’s report on the cause of death. Police are seeking information from the public to help identify her.

A New Zealand couple, Hannah and Alex, built a solar-powered two-bedroom home on the bed of a 1986 Hino flatbed truck after returning from the UK and unable to afford traditional property. Over a year and a half, using steel and wood, they created a nearly self-sufficient residence in Nelson, featuring solar panels, a wood-fired stove, gas for hot water, and spring-sourced water. The $25,000 project offers a cozy, nature-surrounded lifestyle with amenities like stained glass windows and a loft spare room. The couple plans to build a similar home again in the future.

Research from Northwestern University shows that kindergarten children who share iPads in class perform significantly better in early literacy tests than those who use iPads individually or have no iPads, scoring about 30 points higher. The study involved 352 students and suggests that collaborative learning around shared technology enhances literacy outcomes. These findings challenge skepticism about using technology in non-IT classes and imply that schools should reconsider tablet usage in early education to maximize effectiveness.

A piglet born without back legs in Qionglai City, Sichuan Province, China, has become an internet sensation for learning to walk on its two front trotters. Despite frequent wobbling, the piglet, nicknamed "super pig," balances skillfully and mingles with its fully-legged siblings. Videos of its unique walking ability have captured widespread attention and admiration. Similar cases of two-legged animals, like a rabbit at Liuzhou Zoo, have also attracted visitors in China.

During the inaugural IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana on Sunday, Todd Phillips, a front-outside tire changer for Dayle Coyne Racing, was injured when Francesco Dracone's car struck his leg after Dracone spun exiting his pit box on lap 25. Phillips received stitches for a leg cut at the infield care center and was released. The race was challenging due to traction issues caused by rain. Dracone, from Italy, did not finish the race, placing 23rd.

A husband, Milton Vieira Severiano, brutally murdered his dancer wife, Cicera Alves de Sena, in Rio de Janeiro after only four days of marriage. Jealous of men looking at her, he first beat her by smashing her head into concrete 11 times and punching her repeatedly, then shot her in the face five times at close range. Cicera, who performed with the dance troop Jaula das Gostozudas under the stage name Amanda Bueno, was accused by her husband of being a "slut" and "whore" during a violent argument witnessed by neighbors. After the killing, Severiano stole a neighbor’s car but was apprehended by police following a crash; his car contained multiple firearms and a bulletproof vest. He confessed to the murder and now faces life imprisonment.

Sarah Wilson, journalist and author of "I Quit Sugar," revealed her personal struggle with mental illness, including near-suicidal thoughts driven by anxiety, stress, thyroid disease, and isolation. At 41, she spoke candidly about feeling alone and unable to see a future, linking anxiety closely with depression. Wilson emphasized the rising impact of anxiety, particularly among Australian women, calling it the "new depression," and highlighted the need to acknowledge its connection with depression to better address mental health challenges. Support resources like Beyond Blue and Lifeline were also mentioned.

Elena Curtin, a pregnant woman from Portland, Oregon, was charged with second-degree assault after beating her boyfriend's ex-girlfriend with a crowbar for using heroin in her bathroom in November 2014. The ex-girlfriend refused to leave when asked, leading Curtin to use physical force, which Oregon law permits against intruders. Prosecutors dropped the charges, deeming Curtin's actions justified. The ex-girlfriend had a history of harassing Curtin and a shared past with the boyfriend, who struggled with heroin and has since distanced himself from Curtin and their child. Curtin is now living with her parents and has moved on from the toxic situation.

Gemma, a pit bull in California, was filmed being fed treats by her owner, who tried to trick her by including a broccoli spear. Gemma showed disgust, ate the broccoli, then spat it out on the floor. The passage hopes the children she lives with will still learn to enjoy vegetables. Besides eating, Gemma enjoys sleeping and spending time with her human family.

HSBC apologized after a link on its official website, meant for the now-defunct Young Entrepreneur Awards, redirected visitors to a pornographic site. The awards, discontinued in 2011, had allowed the URL registration on hsbc.com.hk to expire, enabling the porn site to take over the address. HSBC removed the offending hyperlink once the issue was discovered, clarified it had no association with the external site, and assured the public that its main website and internet banking services remained secure.

A 13-year-old Maryland boy, Marcus, called 911 after a fire broke out on the first floor of his Clinton home, trapping him and his 9-year-old sister Aaliyah in a second-floor bedroom. During the calm 11-minute call, Marcus provided firefighters with detailed instructions to locate them, comforted his sister, and guided her to stay low and breathe. Firefighters entered the room by breaking a window, rescued Marcus and Aaliyah, and provided the girl with a gas mask. Both siblings were taken to a children's hospital with non-life-threatening injuries, while their mother, stepfather, and older brother escaped and were treated at another hospital.

The passage describes striking images of blue fluorescent algae lighting up Australia's east coast, specifically in Jervis Bay, NSW. Photographer Andy Hutchinson called the scene a "beautiful supernatural" display caused by millions of plankton emitting light. The algae, identified as Noctiluca scintillans, is a single-celled phytoplankton that blooms naturally in spring and autumn. University of New South Wales expert Iain Suthers explained that this carnivorous algae preys on diatoms and emits its luminous glow as a defense mechanism. A similar glowing algae event was observed at Sydney's Manly Beach in August 2014.

New genetic tests, such as Endopredict, can identify markers in breast tumors to determine cancer aggressiveness and recurrence risk, potentially allowing many breast cancer patients to avoid chemotherapy. After surgery, tumor cells are analyzed to provide patients with a risk score within days; a low score (around 5%) indicates chemotherapy may not significantly improve outcomes. Chemotherapy, though commonly prescribed post-surgery, has harsh side effects, leading some patients to seek alternatives. While these tests currently cost around £2,500 and are mostly private, experts advocate for NHS adoption due to cost savings from reduced chemotherapy use. The tests empower patients to make informed treatment decisions, as illustrated by Becca Cornford, whose low-risk score enabled her to forgo chemotherapy without significantly increasing her risk of recurrence.

More than 25 women have been airlifted from Royal Navy ships due to pregnancy, including five emergency medevacs from HMS Ocean over nine years and at least one from HMS Illustrious before its decommissioning. Additional evacuations occurred on 18 other ships such as HMS Dragon and HMS Richmond. A Ministry of Defence (MOD) spokesman confirmed a strict "no touching" policy at sea, indicating pregnancies occurred before boarding or during leave. This data surfaced nine months after Commander Sarah West was flown back to the UK amid allegations of an inappropriate relationship. Women have served on Royal Navy ships since 1990, making up about 9% of personnel in 2014, with notable milestones like the first female submariners in 2015. Similarly, nearly 100 female British soldiers were repatriated from Afghanistan between 2006 and 2013 due to pregnancy, as strict rules prohibit pregnant servicewomen from serving in war zones. Pregnant personnel are evacuated on medical flights, though some pregnancies may occur on deployment. The MOD stated pregnant personnel are returned at the earliest opportunity.

A drone carrying traces of radioactive cesium was found on the rooftop of Japan's prime minister Shinzo Abe's residence, raising terrorism concerns. The drone, equipped with a camera, smoke flares, and a plastic bottle containing small, non-harmful amounts of cesium, was discovered the same day a court approved restarting two nuclear reactors. Officials suspect the cesium was deliberately placed in the drone. Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga highlighted potential terrorism threats involving drones, especially ahead of major events like the Olympics and G7 summit. While drone flights are restricted near airports, there are no such limits around the prime minister’s residence or government buildings. Abe was not present during the incident.

A security guard in Zhejiang, China, Lu Xincai, cares for his 84-year-old mother who has Alzheimer’s by taking her to work daily on his motorbike, securing her with a sash to prevent falls. After his father passed away, with no other caregivers available, he wakes early to prepare her and rides slowly the four kilometers to work, ensuring her safety and companionship during the hour-long journey. At his workplace, a bank, she has her own room, and he frequently checks on her to prevent wandering. Motivated by his mother’s lifelong care for him, Lu feels a strong duty to care for her, saying she was once his "apple," and now he is hers.

The study by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation at the University of Washington, published in the American Journal of Public Health, reveals a 17.2% rise in heavy drinking among Americans between 2005 and 2012, driven mainly by increased alcohol consumption among women. Heavy drinking is defined by the CDC as averaging over one drink per day for women and two for men, while binge drinking involves consuming four or more drinks for women and five or more for men on a single occasion monthly. Women's binge drinking rates increased much faster than men's, with significant regional variations across U.S. counties. Despite rises in heavy drinking, the overall percentage of people drinking alcohol remained stable. The study links these trends to changing social norms, economic factors, lower alcohol prices, increased advertising, and relaxed alcohol regulations. Approximately 88,600 U.S. deaths in 2010 and over $220 billion in annual costs were attributed to excessive drinking. The research analyzed data from 3.7 million adults using CDC's Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System.

UN officials and the World Health Organization warn that doctors are performing caesarean sections too readily, putting women and babies at risk of infections, complications, disability, or death. While the procedure can be life-saving, it should only be done when medically necessary. Currently, over 25% of births in England are by caesarean—more than double since the early 1990s—partly due to planned caesareans for women anxious about natural birth or with certain medical conditions. WHO recommends an ideal caesarean rate of 10-15%, highlighting the higher costs (£2,369 vs. £1,665 for natural birth) and potential health risks. This contrasts with NHS guidelines allowing caesareans without medical need for reasons like tokophobia. Research indicates about 10% of caesareans result in infections.

A woman named Michelle Filkins, 44, from West Wareham, was arrested for breaking into a $800,000 summer home in Edgartown, Martha's Vineyard, living there for at least a week, and selling the owners' belongings in a yard sale. Owner Mark Conklin discovered her inside the home on April 17; she claimed ownership but fled in a gray Nissan pickup truck when police were called. Police found a broken window covered by a blanket and later arrested her after she tried to re-enter the house. Filkins faces charges including breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property. Missing items include furniture, lamps, posters, kitchenware, and a painting. Police urge anyone who received items from the home to return them and offer assistance for restitution. Filkins is scheduled for court on May 14.

Police at Albury on the NSW-Victoria border reunited a lost iPhone with its owner, Bella Crooke from Melbourne, after she lost it at a friend's birthday party. The unlocked phone was handed into the police station, where officers humorously used the phone to post selfies and pun-filled messages on Bella's Facebook page to locate her. The posts, including photos of the phone in a holding cell and jokes about charging and "good behaviour," attracted positive attention and helped identify Bella. She reclaimed the phone without needing to give her name, as officers recognized her from Facebook. Bella appreciated the police’s good humor and has since secured her phone with a password.

A five-day-old baby hippopotamus was thrown into the air and mauled to death during a violent fight between two adult male hippos in the Isimangaliso Wetland Park, South Africa. The calf's mother watched helplessly while trying to protect her baby from younger hippos but could not prevent one sub-adult from grabbing the calf in its jaws and flinging it. Despite the mother's attempts to intervene, the calf sustained fatal injuries and died hours later. A nearby tour operator witnessed the tragic event.

A three-bedroom, 1,990 sq/ft apartment in Knightsbridge, one of Britain's most expensive areas, is on sale for £575,000, markedly below neighboring property prices, but it has only three years left on its lease. The unmodernized maisonette requires renovation and includes two bathrooms, a reception room, a utility room, lift access, parking, and a communal garden. The low price equates to about £191,000 per year, similar to local rental rates. Extending the lease—likely costing between £3.35 million and £4.5 million to add 90 years—could increase the property's value to over £6 million; a larger adjoining property could be worth £7.5 million after modernization. The freeholder is likely the Welcome Trust, and lease extensions require negotiation. The flats, built circa 1893 in Egerton Place, feature historic architecture. Experts warn that while the price seems a bargain, the costly lease extension is a significant factor; such short lease sales are rare in Knightsbridge. The property has attracted strong interest from locals, developers, and end-users despite the upcoming election period.

Starbucks experienced a computer outage on Friday evening affecting registers at 8,000 stores in the US and Canada, disrupting credit card and sales transactions. The issue, caused by a failure during a daily system refresh, led many stores to give away free drinks and baked goods before closing early to avoid further giveaways. Some locations accepted cash despite the glitch, while others closed entirely. The outage also impacted Evolution Fresh and Teavana stores but was resolved by Saturday with business returning to normal. The incident occurred just after Starbucks reported record quarterly earnings of $4.6 billion and a 4.4% gain in share price. Customers shared their experiences and free drink photos widely on social media during the disruption.

Terrorists are reportedly undergoing training and radicalising activities in rural areas of West Wales, specifically in Ceredigion, Powys, and Pembrokeshire. According to Detective Constable Gareth Jones of the Wales Extremism and Counter Terrorism Unit, individuals involved participate in normal community activities but with hidden extremist motives. Terrorist activity in Wales dates back to 1998 with extremists trained in the Brecon Beacons, a military training area known for its rugged terrain. Notable incidents include the 7/7 bombers photographed in North Wales in 2005 and a failed 2010 plot by a Cardiff-based al-Qaeda inspired gang. Michael Adebowale, convicted of murdering Fusilier Lee Rigby, studied Arabic at the former European Institute of Human Sciences near Llanybydder, established by Iraqi clerics. DC Jones emphasized that rural Wales locations have been used for radicalisation and that community intelligence is vital for counter-terrorism efforts.

A juvenile female Omura's whale, a species feared extinct and first described scientifically in 2003, was found washed up on a remote West Australian beach after Cyclone Olwyn. This is the species' first sighting in Western Australia and only the second in Australia. Identification was confirmed via DNA profiling by Department of Parks and Wildlife staff. The find is significant as little is known about the whale, which is typically found in tropical and subtropical waters like Indonesia, the Philippines, and the Sea of Japan. The Omura's whale has distinctive features such as a sleek body, 53 vertebrae, and four digits on each pectoral fin. Its carcass has been buried, with plans to recover the skeleton for further scientific study and potential museum display.

The passage discusses the role of hormones in evaluating presidential candidates, highlighting a Texas businesswoman Cheryl Rios's belief that women’s hormones make them unsuitable for presidency, contrasted with the historical male-driven risky decisions fueled by testosterone. It emphasizes scientific studies showing women leaders take fewer unnecessary risks and addresses pervasive gender bias against women in leadership, despite their qualifications and achievements. The passage critiques societal biases that hinder women’s progress, noting the benefits of gender equality for businesses, families, and society. It concludes that while Hillary Clinton may face challenges as a female candidate, overcoming gender bias is essential for true equality, correcting a misconception about Canada’s first female prime minister.

Veteran actor Robert Hardy, known for roles such as Siegfried Farnon in "All Creatures Great and Small," Winston Churchill, and Cornelius Fudge in "Harry Potter," is auctioning over 200 antiques and collectibles worth around £100,000 as he downsizes his home in the Cotswolds. The auction, held by Dominic Winter Auctioneers in Gloucestershire, features diverse items including a hand-painted limewood diorama of the Battle of Agincourt, a yew longbow with a mother-of-pearl handle, paintings, Victorian furniture, swords, rifles, silverware, chandeliers, and rare books dating back to the 17th century. Hardy, an expert military historian and scholar who studied under J.R.R. Tolkien and C.S. Lewis at Oxford, has also authored books on the medieval longbow and contributed to historical projects like the Mary Rose shipwreck. Despite retiring from stage acting due to a fall, he intends to continue television work. Hardy expressed sadness about parting with his treasured collection but hopes new owners find as much joy in the items as he did.

Michael Scott Shemansky, wanted as a suspect in the murder of his mother Sandra Shemansky in Winter Garden, Florida, has been on the run since Saturday. Sandra, 57, was found dead in their shared home following a welfare check after Michael missed a supervised visit with his son. Authorities confirmed foul play and possess the murder weapon but have not disclosed the cause of death. Michael has a history of bipolar disorder, prior battery on law enforcement, and was involuntarily committed after a suicide attempt. His estranged wife, who obtained a domestic violence injunction against him two years ago, confirmed his missed visitation. Neighbors believe divorce stress and his mother’s attempts to protect him from court troubles contributed to the incident. Michael was last seen fleeing on foot from the scene without provisions or medication. Authorities urge anyone with information to call 407-656-3636.

The city of Eugene, USA, has been awarded the rights to host the 2021 IAAF World Championships. The International Association of Athletics Federations (IAAF) council bypassed the usual bidding process, citing a unique strategic opportunity to host the event in the USA for the first time. Eugene had previously failed in its bid for the 2019 championships, which were awarded to Doha, Qatar. IAAF President Lamine Diack emphasized the strategic importance of the decision, highlighting the collaboration of public authorities, private sector, the National Olympic Committee, NBC, and public enthusiasm. The 2007 championships in Osaka were also awarded without bidding.

Leonie Granger, a 25-year-old aspiring model from Gillingham, Kent, was jailed for 16 years after being found guilty of manslaughter in the death of professional gambler Mehmet Hassan, 56. Granger lured Hassan, whom she befriended at a London casino using her looks, to his Islington flat under the pretense of a date. After she left the door unlocked, her boyfriend Kyrron Jackson and accomplice Nicholas Chandler entered, tied up Hassan, and fatally kicked him while searching for his hidden cash winnings. Hassan, a vulnerable gambler known for keeping large sums of money at home, died from a brutal attack. Jackson and Chandler were convicted of murder and sentenced to life imprisonment with a minimum of 36 years. The court described the crime as “pitiless and wicked,” motivated by ruthless greed. Granger expressed regret, attributing her involvement to her relationship with Jackson. The defendants were also convicted of robbery and conspiracy to falsely imprison Hassan.

Chelsea midfielder Cesc Fàbregas has shown a recurring pattern of struggling in the second half of the season, evident in his poor performance during Spain's 2-0 loss to Holland and his dip in form since January. After a strong start following his £30 million move from Barcelona, where he seemed set to break the Premier League assist record, his contributions have declined significantly, with only one assist in his last five games and four in 15 appearances in 2015. Despite fatigue from playing nearly every minute for Chelsea, manager José Mourinho remains hopeful that Fàbregas will regain form to help secure the Premier League title, especially as Chelsea faces several opponents he has previously assisted goals against. His recent assist to Diego Costa suggests a possible late-season resurgence.

West Ham United are in talks to sign Jamaican 17-year-old forward Deshane Beckford, who impressed during a two-week trial with their academy. Beckford, from Montego Bay United, has attracted interest from Belgian clubs and is considered a top Caribbean prospect. Additionally, West Ham have announced season ticket prices at the Olympic Stadium starting from £289, the lowest in the Premier League, aiming to fill the 54,000-seat venue for the 2016-17 season.

Police have dropped their investigation into a violent assault on Mike Lane, 40, joint master of the Tedworth Hunt, which occurred three months prior despite substantial evidence identifying suspects. Lane was attacked by balaclava-clad protesters wielding iron bars and suffered concussion, broken teeth, memory loss, and facial injuries. A video and detailed evidence, including names and car registrations of saboteurs, were provided to Wiltshire Police, but no arrests have been made. Police cited insufficient evidence for shelving the case, angering Lane and supporters who criticize the police effort. The incident involved around 15 protesters distracting hounds with citronella, with a core group engaging violently. The Countryside Alliance is pushing for a ban on face coverings among saboteurs to aid prosecutions. Wiltshire Police said the case remains open pending new evidence but is currently undetected.

Adam Gadahn, a U.S.-born prominent English-language propagandist for al Qaeda known as "Azzam the American," was killed in January during a U.S. counterterrorism operation, announced by the White House. Born in 1978 in California to a family that changed their name from Pearlman, Gadahn converted to Islam in 1995 and left for Pakistan in 1998 to join al Qaeda, adopting the alias Abu Suhayb. He rose to prominence post-9/11, appearing in threatening al Qaeda videos targeting Western countries and urging Muslims to attack American, Western, and Jewish interests. Indicted in 2006 for treason and material support to al Qaeda, he was listed among the FBI's most wanted terrorists. Gadahn criticized U.S. presidents, called for lone-wolf attacks in the U.S., praised attacks like Fort Hood and Benghazi, and advocated overthrowing governments in Saudi Arabia and Pakistan. He played an increasing institutional role in al Qaeda, contributing to media strategy documents recovered from Osama bin Laden's compound. Gadahn was married to an Afghan Muslim woman and had at least one child. Another U.S. citizen and al Qaeda operative, Ahmed Farouq, also died in a likely separate strike, which killed U.S. hostage Warren Weinstein and Italian hostage Giovanni Lo Porto.

The passage describes a viral video in China featuring five-year-old Mai Zizhuo, a child prodigy with exceptional basketball skills developed since age two and a half. His impressive ability to score hoops and dribble two basketballs simultaneously has captivated basketball fans nationwide, drawing thousands of amazed comments online. Mai is seen as a rising basketball star, following in the footsteps of the country's biggest star, Yao Ming. The video has sparked admiration and surprise among netizens, some questioning if special effects were used and others feeling humbled by Mai's talent.

Tom O'Carroll, a former key activist of the notorious Paedophile Information Exchange (PIE), which campaigned to legalize child sex in the 1970s and 80s, has joined supporters of the media pressure group Hacked Off. He attended a Hacked Off rally at the Houses of Parliament on February 25, chaired by comedian John Cleese, advocating for statutory state regulation of the press, following recommendations from the Leveson Inquiry. PIE, founded in 1974, sought to legalize sex with children and incest, and allied with the National Council for Civil Liberties (NCCL), which lobbied to lower the age of consent to ten. O'Carroll was also involved in the NCCL's gay rights sub-committee and was jailed in 1981 for "corrupting public morals." Hacked Off stated the rally was open to all members of the public, though O'Carroll's association is expected to embarrass the group.

The iconic Bondi Icebergs Club pool was drained on Thursday to host a unique catwalk event for Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia, showcasing the "Ten Pieces" unisex capsule collection by Maurice Terzini and Lucy Hinckfuss. Models presented ten monochrome pieces, designed to be worn in 20 different ways suitable for day-to-night wear, by walking through the empty pool and along the break wall against the ocean backdrop. Guests enjoyed food, drinks, and warm weather while spectators including beachgoers and passers-by gathered to watch the minimalist, androgynous fashion show.

Bolton-born boxer Amir Khan spent a family day at Six Flags Discovery Kingdom, a safari park in Northern California, where he fed a rare white tiger and posed with giraffes and sea lions alongside his wife Faryal Makhdoom Khan and daughter Lamysa. Earlier in the week, Khan announced his next fight against former light-welterweight world champion Chris Algieri on May 30, dismissing speculation about bouts with British rival Kell Brook, Adrien Broner, or Keith Thurman.

A Palestinian teenager, Mohammed Abu Khdeir, who was beaten and burned alive by three Israelis in July, had his name added to an Israeli memorial for fallen soldiers and terror victims at Jerusalem's Mount Herzl. His family and the group Almagor opposed this inclusion, with his father refusing to have his son listed among soldiers of the occupation and Almagor labeling the death a rogue attack, not terrorism. After objections and a complaint by Almagor to Israel's National Insurance Institute, the agency agreed to remove Abu Khdeir’s name from the memorial. Meanwhile, a court case against the suspects in his killing began in January.

A California-based YouTube user, Lionel Hutz, filmed his young son trying to use their cat as a pillow in the garden. The cat initially tolerates the boy resting on it but repeatedly moves away when disturbed, leading the boy to follow and repeat the process. Eventually, the cat walks indoors, tired of being used as a pillow. A later video shows the boy and cat reconciling, with the boy feeding the cat treats.

The ongoing Philadelphia police corruption trial features testimony from over a dozen former drug dealers, including Robert Kushner, who admitted to selling marijuana and testified about undercover officers stealing money and drugs during his 2007 arrest. Kushner, 32, lost his varsity coaching job at Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy after officials learned of his past, despite him passing a background check and his 2007 charges being expunged. He also acknowledged a 2011 arrest and a 2008 DUI conviction. Kushner expressed remorse and insists he did not intend to deceive the school. The accused officers face charges including racketeering and extortion, while their lawyers claim the government's case relies on testimony from lying drug dealers and a rogue ex-cop.

A chemical plant producing paraxylene (PX) in Zhangzhou, Fujian province, China, experienced an explosion and large fire after an oil leak. Six people were injured, mostly from broken glass, and hospitalized. Over 600 firefighters controlled the blaze. The plant had a prior explosion in 2013 without casualties. PX plants have sparked protests in China over pollution concerns. Originally planned near Xiamen, the Zhangzhou plant was relocated after backlash due to pollution fears.

Jack Grealish, an Aston Villa teenager and Ireland U21 international, insists on wearing his socks low above his children's-size shinpads due to superstition, despite referees advising him otherwise. He made his first Premier League start in a challenging 3-3 draw against QPR, expressing satisfaction with gaining the opportunity and appreciation for his manager's faith, hoping for more starts before the season ends.

Bobbi Kristina Brown, daughter of Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston, has suffered global and irreversible brain damage and remains unresponsive despite being out of a medically induced coma, according to her grandmother Cissy Houston and medical sources. She shows no reaction to visitors and has a tracheostomy. While Bobby Brown stated she is awake and watching him, the family’s attorney emphasized that although she may live a long life, her quality of life and recovery outcomes are uncertain and will require a lengthy rehabilitation. Bobby Brown’s wife added that Bobbi Kristina has left the ICU and begun a challenging rehab process.

Russia is close to reaching the Fed Cup final with a 2-0 lead over Germany after Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova saved a match point to defeat Sabine Lisicki 4-6, 7-6 (4), 6-3. Earlier, Svetlana Kuznetsova beat Julia Goerges in straight sets. Despite Pavlyuchenkova's 13 double faults and Lisicki's 63 unforced errors, Pavlyuchenkova prevailed. Russia now needs one win from the remaining three matches to secure their first Fed Cup title since 2008.

Residents of New South Wales, recovering from last week's severe storm and flooding caused by an east coast low, are being warned of another potential storm bringing heavy rain from Thursday to Saturday. The State Emergency Service (SES) is overwhelmed, with over 4,000 of 24,196 assistance jobs still incomplete, particularly concerned about the heavily affected Hunter region. Meteorologists indicate the new east coast low will differ from last week's, likely causing two days of rain primarily in northern coastal areas rather than Sydney, though heavy rainfall and flooding risks remain, especially in already saturated catchments. Authorities urge communities to prepare for further damage while SES teams, including personnel from other states, continue clean-up and readiness efforts. The Bureau of Meteorology notes it is too early to confirm the new system's severity but anticipates increased rainfall peaking later in the week.

Nina Moric, a model known for appearing in Ricky Martin's "La Vida Loca" video, denied reports that she attempted suicide after collapsing from low blood pressure. Despite Italian media and her boyfriend Luigi Mario Favoloso claiming she tried to take her own life and was found by her mother at their Milan apartment, Moric clarified on Instagram that she suffered a domestic accident causing bruising and a head injury. She was treated in hospital and is now recovering at home. Moric expressed shock at the suicide rumors, stating her boyfriend was in Naples at the time. Previously, Italian media reported a 2009 suicide attempt. Moric is Croatian-born, was married to paparazzo Fabrizio Corona—who served jail time for blackmail—and they have a son born in 2002. Corona admitted in phone taps to ruining lives, though he denied blackmailing celebrities.

A YouGov poll found that among Britons, the favorite name for Kate and William’s second child is Diana, honoring William’s late mother, the Princess of Wales, with 12% support. Other popular girl names include Alice and Charlotte (each 9%), while for a boy, James (13%) and Alexander are preferred. The poll showed a strong desire for a baby girl, with 25% hoping for a princess, and just 3% wanting a younger brother for Prince George. Social media users expressed enthusiasm for the name Diana. Additionally, 68% of respondents supported William taking six weeks of paternity leave from his pilot job.

A suicide bomber attacked protesters in Khost, eastern Afghanistan, killing 17 and injuring 64, including an Afghan lawmaker. The protesters were en route to a larger rally against the provincial governor. The Taliban denied responsibility, and no group has claimed the attack.

Dani Alves is set to leave Barcelona this summer after rejecting the club's final contract offer. Despite seven successful years at Barcelona, including winning four Spanish titles and two Champions League trophies, Alves, 31, was unable to agree on a new deal. His agent confirmed the negotiations ended after Alves declined a three-year extension contingent on playing in 60% of matches.

Pablo Osvaldo, currently on loan at Boca Juniors from Southampton and having scored three goals in six games, has urged Italian legends Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti to join him at the Argentine club. Osvaldo believes their South American-style play would suit Boca Juniors perfectly and that the fans would be thrilled to see them at La Bombonera. He regards Pirlo as one of the world's best midfielders and Totti as a Roma legend who would be equally beloved in Argentina.

Amateur jockey 18-year-old Lewis Ferguson suffered a spectacular double somersault fall during a race at Wincanton but escaped with only a cut on his nose. Despite the fall making him an internet sensation with hundreds of thousands of views, Ferguson was back at Paul Nicholls' yard the next morning, continuing stable duties and showing no fear about riding again. He described the fall as a blur, was supported by fellow jockeys, and joked about possibly pursuing gymnastics after racing.

The passage highlights rugby player James Haskell's enthusiasm for the newly released Avengers: Age of Ultron movie, showcased by his Instagram post dressed as Iron Man. The film premiered in London with stars like Robert Downey Jr., Chris Hemsworth, and Scarlett Johansson. Haskell, captain of the London Wasps, initially joined the club in 2002, later moving to teams in France, Japan, and New Zealand between 2009 and 2012. He returned to Wasps in 2012, surpassing 100 appearances and earning 57 caps for England, becoming a key player in the national squad.

The wide-leg trouser is a key SS15 fashion trend, offering an effortless alternative to skinny jeans, which have dominated for years. Popular in denim, cropped, printed, or striped styles, the wide leg silhouette recalls 1970s fashion and has been featured by designers like Gucci, Celine, and Stella McCartney. Styling tips include pairing wide-leg trousers with high-heeled shoes to elongate the leg, keeping tops simple to maintain proportion, and opting for high-waisted, long-length pants to enhance leg length. Denim is highlighted as the easiest fabric to adopt the trend, with high street options like Topshop’s Miller jean and more affordable labels like Finery London providing accessible versions. The trend suits various occasions, from casual to dressy, and is practical for all weather, making it a versatile update for spring wardrobes.

The University of Michigan decided to proceed with screening the film "American Sniper" despite objections from over 200 students who petitioned against it, citing the movie's negative portrayal of the Middle East. The university initially canceled but later reversed the decision, emphasizing freedom of expression and student choice. The screening is part of UMix social events, with a family-friendly alternative, "Paddington," also offered. The decision received praise from football coach Jim Harbaugh.

Two French tourists on Rottnest Island, Western Australia, ignited an aerosol spray with a lighter, causing a flame to singe a quokka, a small marsupial native to the area. The quokka survived the incident. The 18- and 24-year-old men were questioned by detectives, evicted from the island, and charged with animal cruelty. They are set to appear in Fremantle Magistrates Court on April 17.

Alice Barker, a 102-year-old former dancer in notable New York nightclubs during the 1930s and 1940s, had never seen footage or photos of herself dancing because her memorabilia was lost. Filmmaker Mark Cantor and volunteers compiled early music videos ("soundies") featuring her performances and showed them to her at her nursing home, bringing her great joy.

The passage reports a decline in the tradition of washing cars at home in Britain. A study of 1,100 adults by vehicle leasing firm OSV found that a third of men and three-quarters of women have never washed their own cars, with only a small percentage doing it regularly. Factors contributing to this decline include Sunday shopping, increased live football broadcasts, the popularity of hand car washes, and larger vehicle sizes making washing more difficult. While holiday periods see more car washing by owners, overall motivation is low, with only a few involving children to help for pocket money. Car washing is most frequent in cities like Birmingham and least in places like Oxford. Audis, Toyotas, and BMWs are washed more often by owners, whereas Range Rovers, Peugeots, and Mercedes are washed least. OSV highlights that the tradition of Sunday car washing has faded due to time constraints, bigger cars, lack of interest from children, and the convenience of professional or automated car washes.

Martin Skrtel has praised Steven Gerrard's significant influence since joining Liverpool in 2008, highlighting Gerrard as one of the world's best players and synonymous with the club. Gerrard is set to play in the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, aiming to lead Liverpool to a final against Arsenal on his birthday, May 30, after which he will leave for LA Galaxy. Skrtel credits Gerrard for helping him settle at Liverpool and acknowledges that while Gerrard's departure will change the team, Liverpool has potential replacements for him. Both players are expected to return for the semi-final after serving suspensions.

At 75, Jack Nicklaus made a memorable hole-in-one during the par-3 contest at Augusta National, hitting an ace on the 130-yard fourth hole. Playing alongside Gary Player and Ben Crenshaw, Nicklaus celebrated his first-ever hole-in-one at Augusta, though five total aces were made that day, tying the 2002 record. Camilo Villegas notably made two aces but lost in a playoff to Kevin Streelman. Nicklaus, the youngest green jacket winner in 1963 with six total Masters titles, is one of five men to complete the career grand slam—a feat that Rory McIlroy could achieve by winning his third consecutive major.

Several storms on Wednesday night triggered tornado sirens in Kansas, with tornado reports near Goddard and southwestern Kansas, including around Aetna. A tornado possibly touched down in Potosi, Missouri, causing wind damage and flooding. Nighttime tornadoes were highlighted as especially dangerous. Additional storm damage included large hail and flooding in Missouri. More storms were expected on Thursday across the Midwest, Mississippi and Tennessee river valleys, and near the southern Great Lakes.

Robert Bates, a 73-year-old Oklahoma reserve sheriff's deputy, pleaded not guilty to second-degree manslaughter for fatally shooting Eric Harris, which Bates claims was an accidental use of a gun instead of a taser during a weapons sting operation. Despite the charge, the judge allowed Bates to vacation in the Bahamas, prompting criticism from Harris's family, who view the trip as insensitive. Bates's preliminary hearing is set for July 2, with his lawyer emphasizing a focus on courtroom facts over media. Allegations arose that Bates was unqualified and received preferential treatment due to donations and connections, including claims of forged records by supervisors, which the sheriff's office denies. Bates's legal team released his training records to counter these claims. Two deputies involved in the arrest were reassigned due to threats against them. Sheriff Stanley Glanz and Bates have apologized to the Harris family.

Conor McGregor is preparing to challenge José Aldo for the featherweight title on July 11 in Las Vegas. Ahead of the fight, McGregor unveiled a new tiger tattoo on his stomach, symbolizing his fierce mentality. He believes Aldo lacks the motivation to defend the belt, claiming Aldo "doesn't want this the way I want it." The two fighters have a tense relationship, highlighted during a promotional tour in Dublin where McGregor took Aldo's belt and showed it to his home supporters. Aldo will be making his eighth title defense against the highly motivated McGregor.

Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott faced criticism after he enthusiastically skolling a schooner of beer at an Australian rules football event, with anti-drinking campaigners and cultural studies professor Julie Robert condemning the act for glorifying binge drinking and reinforcing harmful masculine stereotypes. While Abbott was cheered by players and defended by Health Minister Sussan Ley, critics argued that, despite drinking being part of Australian culture, such displays promote irresponsible alcohol consumption. The incident also drew media and political reactions, including opposition leader Bill Shorten's remarks. Professor Robert highlighted changing societal attitudes towards heavy drinking and emphasized the need for leaders to set better examples. Abbott's behavior mirrored past prime ministers' drinking antics but was controversial due to current concerns over binge drinking.

Indiana is experiencing a significant HIV outbreak in Scott County, largely linked to intravenous drug use of the painkiller Opana. Since Gov. Mike Pence approved a 30-day emergency needle exchange program on March 26, confirmed HIV cases have risen from 106 to 120, with 10 preliminary positives. The program has distributed over 5,300 clean syringes and collected about 1,400 used ones, aided by mobile units building trust among users.

Pence is reviewing the situation and expected to decide soon on extending the program beyond April 25. However, he opposes needle exchanges as a drug policy, creating uncertainty about the program’s future and legislation that would allow other counties with high hepatitis C rates to start similar initiatives. The Indiana Senate is divided on the issue, expressing concerns that exchanges might encourage drug use, while supporters argue it is a necessary harm-reduction strategy.

Funding is also a challenge since federal public funding for needle exchanges has been banned since 1989, and no state funds were allocated in Pence’s order. Health officials warn that the response has been short-term and insufficient to address the ongoing risk of HIV spread in Indiana.

An obsessive Arsenal fan created a detailed Arsenal-themed exam for his girlfriend, Saskia, testing her knowledge about the club with multiple-choice questions, squad line-ups, and opinion-based answers. Saskia scored an impressive 43.5 out of 50 (87%), earning praise and sparing her from being dumped. The test included questions on player positions, match scores, and club history, with Saskia showing some confusion on player roles but offering creative answers, notably about Alexis Sanchez. Her boyfriend marked her work seriously, correcting mistakes and expressing his passion for Arsenal, including a note that "Tottenham are scum." Saskia shared the exam on Twitter, garnering admiration from football fans who called her "proper gf material," while some thought the boyfriend’s approach was extreme. Overall, the lighthearted exchange highlighted their relationship dynamics and sparked engagement among football fans on social media.
